story:
The Answers Recovery Program

The ANSWERS Recovery Program®  (The Program) will recruit families of children with autism, ADHD, asthma, allergies, chronic Lyme, environmental illness or other chronic illnesses and provide them with FREE professional healing services and support in an effort to help each child attain optimal health.  By demonstrating that children can recover from these conditions, The Program hopes to change the current paradigm through which we view chronic disease in America. 

The ultimate goal of The Program is to help families in their quest to achieve the greatest health potential for their children while documenting the successes and challenges of children as they recover.  We will be making a documentary film of this project in collaboration with Mary Mazzio, of 50 Eggs Productions.  The film will serve as an inspiration for families looking for answers for their children, but also as an expose on the environmental factors contributing to the epidemics of autism, ADHD, allergies and other conditions.

What We Need Today & Why:

We need the initial $50,000 so we can get the program up and running.  Additional funds will be needed to complete the documentary film project, but initial $50,000 will pay for:

  • Project website and outreach materials to garner sponsorships from important healthcare partners including diagnostics, supplement, holistic health, green cleaning, and organic food and personal care products (these donations/sponsorships of products/services will be given directly to the participating families)
  • Administrative costs to recruit families and prepare them for the program
  • Legal and administrative costs necessary to set up the program
  • Additional fundraising events so that we can raise more money to support as many as 10 children.
  • Books and educational materials (on health and wellness) for the participating families

Other Ways You Can Help

Sign up to be a volunteer today.  Epidemic Answers is an all-volunteer organization and we can use all the help we can get!  Have a special talent or skill?  We can probably use it!  Examples include:

  • Web design/tech support
  • Marketing expertise
  • Graphics/art
  • PR and promotional work
  • Event planning
  • Networking, blogging, social media
  • Fundraising
  • Grantwriting
  • Ask if you don't see your talent/expertise listed here!

Email Beth@epidemicanswers.org for more information

Spread the word!!!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, we are Step by Step Foundation, a non-profit organization, and we need your help. As many of you have heard in the news, there have been ongoing fires in the Colorado area. Thousands of families have been forced to leave their homes, leaving everything they have behind.

At Step by Step Foundation, our mission is to enhance the lives of underprivileged children by creating and supporting, health, nutrition, water, education and other programs that substantially impact the human rights and development of children worldwide. Thus, we have made an alliance with Colorado Horse Park Foundation to help us with this campaign.

The campaign seeks to provide children with school backpacks that we have filled with school supplies (such as pencils, paper, rulers, erasers, pencil sharpeners, notebooks, among others) and distribute them to children who have lost everything. This will not only ensure that they have the supplies necessary to go to school, but it will also restore the feeling of owning something that is their own.



What We Need & What You Get

For every $25 you give us, a child receives a backpack with school supplies, and you recieve a Step by Step Foundation wristband.

For every $50 or more that you give us, 2+ children recieve backpacks with school supplies, and you recieve a Step by Step Foundation wristband and a Step by Step Foundation Medal.

The Impact

We will reach as many children as the amount of our donations will allow us.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help, but cannot help us with donations, its okay. Please use the Share Tool provided by Indiegogo, and share our campaign with all of your family and friends and help us help these children!

Also please visit our website at www.stepbystepfoundation.com and follow us on Facebook and Twitter @StepbyStepOrg to see other ways how you can help.

story:
Please help us to put this extremely intelligent young man into school!


Adrian is and has always been very observant and bright. In these short four years we have seen just how advanced he is. He began walking and talking early and it seems he went from first words straight into paragraphs overnight!  Those of you who know him can probably remember commenting on his precociousness.

He learns things very quickly and can apply them in the correct context. We had him enrolled in a preschool program in our area from the age of two and although we love and think highly of the staff and teachers, we just could not afford to keep him enrolled. We have continued to have him learn at home and he is doing well, but with the need for both of us to work, it is a struggle to stay ahead of his facility. 

We began looking for schools that would really challenge him and that had scholarship programs. In the meantime, Adrian has cabin fever and withdrawal from the social and structural aspects of going to school. No matter how many play dates, activities, and learning programs we have him do, it is just not the same. He continues to ask for school everyday.

Our challenge outside of the finances, is that where we live public schools will not let him into school because he was not four by their deadline, and he will have to go into pre-k next year because of his late birthday. It is unfair to hinder this child`s education just because of when he was born! He is smart, already learning to spell and to do simple math equations. 

Even with the financial aid that we will be applying for, we will still be responsible for a good portion of the cost. The hope is to re enroll him in the school he was at for the remainder of this school year and then transfer him to the Lowell School.

Even if he does not stay in private school forever, he will be at his correct level when he does go into the public school system. We are just trying to lay the foundation here.

We are reaching out to family and friends asking that you help us to put together the money to help with the tuition for a private school that will place him where he needs to be based on his scholastic potential. We greatly appreciate any donation or assistance you are able to give. We will all benefit from this when Adrian cures cancer, becomes a future President or both.

Our family attended a school tour at the Lowell School in Washington DC (http://www.lowellschool.org/). Adrian fit right in and was very cooperative as he sat in on the lesson for the day. The staff was very welcoming and invited him to enroll. We are hoping that this campaign will succeed so that he can go to a school where he can thrive.

Please share this with friends and family so that they may also support our campaign to get Adrian back into school.

We are doing everything, including changing our living situation to make sure that we can make this happen for him. Adrian means the world to us and deserves to have a chance at success in life.

story:
We are current students (Isiah Baskins, Tianni Stancil, Chloe Nunez, Nasyria Taylor and Moctar Toure) at the NYC iSchool located in downtown Manhattan. Our school specializes in creating a 21st century learning environment. We were invited to the DML Conference in Boston to conduct a workshop on physical computing.However, we lack the funds to cover our trip expenses!

We were originally brought together by a class that our school introduced this year called Physical Computing. Many of us were very new to programming aside from the occasional tumblr theme modification. Our teacher, Ms. Jenkins, took more of a hands off approach when it came to student’s dilemmas. She would ask us to share these issues with the community around us and try to crowd source a solution. This not only helped us grow as a group, but it also helped us communicate our ideas with people that could and also help us improve upon these ideas.

Participants will leave the workshop with a better understanding of how a simple circuit works and how a Lilypad is being programed to do different things. They will be exposed to the possibilities that technology like this can bring to educational environments. This youth-led workshop will also show how adult educators can be learners in a classroom setting. A student and teacher may face the same frustration and misunderstanding when learning something new. This will put us, the workshop’s presenters, in the position of the teacher explain or to help “students” solve problems themselves.

Recently, we have traveled to Philadelphia to attend Educon to conduct the same workshop and it was a success. We are eager to continue the success at the DML Conference in March! Like we stated before we need a little help getting us there. So here's the breakdown:

$50 per student for conference registration + $100 for teacher = $50 x 5 + $100 = $350  $150 per night for three hotel rooms (separate teacher, boy and girl rooms) = $450

round trip bus ticket is $40 per person x 7 people = $280 
= $1080 total

We forget to account for indiegogo fees, so our goal will be $1,200. The fees will take $80 from our total!

As you all can see, we need to raise quite a bit of money in less than 3 weeks but we CAN do it with your help! Thank you so much and don't forget to share with family and friends!

We would like to thank everyone for donating! We are getting so much closer to our goal and of course BOSTON! Again, thank you so much and we genuinely appreciate it :)

story: My name is Marwan Atif Wadi. I am a paramedic watching storm Huda wreak havoc on homeless children devastated and traumatised by the memories of war. My motto has always been to be a point of change. Please help me to be the connection between you and these innocent children, be their blanket of warmth, their sun and light, their helping hand to show them that they have not been left alone to die. As an advocate for survival and health, these children need hats, warm clothing and proper footwear to ensure they can resist this storm and winter weather conditions without shelter.

story:
(Espanol al final de la pagina)

My name is Herceny Del Cid, I was born in El Rodeo, Guatemala. In 1990 I was very fortunate to be able to move to Los Angeles, California and receive an education. However, I never forgot my little village that I knew as a young girl. With the help and guidance of my amazing father Lino, my wonderful mother Marina and my brother Kevin, I began a private charity to give back to my childhood community and give the children in my village and surrounding villages, in Santa Rosa Guatemala an opportunity for an education. The proceeds go directly into the hands of the children in the form of school supplies, soccer equipment and food. Most of the children in these villages cannot afford to buy school supplies and without them they cannot go to school.  

Prior to starting the charity I spent my free time going back to El Rodeo volunteering my time, teaching English to the children at various schools. In 2006 my father organized several charitable "pot lucks" to raise money in hopes to build a soccer field in my village. With the help of all the generous donations from our Los Angeles community, we successfully bought a plot of land and built the soccer field! It is called "Estadio Los Angeles" in honor of the generous donation made by the Los Angeles people.

My father Lino, who inspired me to start this charity in 2011 sadly died of stomach cancer in July of 2013. A battle NOT lost but merely ended. I dedicate this charity to him and would like to continue giving back to my Guatemalan community in his honor, and inspire others to do the same.

The charity work can only continue with the support from people like you. Your kind donations will give the children of Guatemala an opportunity for an education and with that education they can help and inspire their community to thrive and prosper. Just a little goes a long way! With your gift, you will help to fulfill these children's hopes and dreams for a better future.

Mi nombre es Herceny Del Cid, nací en El Rodeo, Guatemala. En 1990 yo fui muy afortunado de venir a Los Ángeles, California, y recibir una educación. Nunca me e olvidado de mi pequeño pueblo que yo conoci cuando era niña. Con la ayuda y la orientación de mi padre Lino, mi maravillosa madre Marina y mi hermano Kevin, comencé una caridad privada para devolver a mi comunidad y dar a los niños de mi pueblo y de pueblos de los alrededores, en Santa Rosa Guatemala una oportunidad para una educación. Los ingresos hechos aqui van directamente a las manos de los niños en forma de útiles escolares, equipo de fútbol y comida. La mayoría de los niños en estos pueblos no pueden permitirse el lujo de comprar los útiles escolares y sin ellos no pueden ir a la escuela.

Antes de iniciar la caridad pasava tiempo ensenado ingles en la escuela del Rodeo. En 2006 mi padre organizó varias quermes con otros familaires de caridad para recaudar dinero con la esperanza de construir un campo de fútbol en mi pueblo. Con la ayuda de todas las generosas donaciones de nuestra comunidad de Los Ángeles, compramos con éxito un terreno y construyeron el campo de fútbol! Se llama "Estadio de Los Ángeles", en honor a la generosa donación realizada por la gente de Los Ángeles.

Mi padre Lino, quien me inspiró a comenzar esta caridad en 2011, lamentablemente murió de cáncer de estómago en julio de 2013.  Dedico esta caridad a él y me gustaría seguir dando  a mi comunidad guatemalteca en su honor, e inspirar a otros a hacer lo mismo.

El trabajo de caridad sólo puede continuar con el apoyo de personas como usted. Sus amables donaciones darán a los niños de Guatemala una oportunidad para una educación y con la educación que pueden ayudar e inspirar a su comunidad a crecer y prosperar.  Con su regalo, usted ayudará a cumplir con las esperanzas y los sueños de estos niños para un futuro mejor. Gracias.

story:
Short Summary

I am Susan Vitacco, mother of a 4 year old who has had great success in learning with a tablet since the age of 2 and I want to share that with other children and schools do not have the means to provide them. I was hoping to donate one myself, until I realized the cost is beyond my means. It is important to get the proper PC

Donate, even just one dollar. It is less dissappointing to have everyone donating a dollar...than everyone not donating at all. That is how this works!!! Everyone who reads my campaign only needs to donate a small amount.

What We Need & What You Get

I would need $5077 for a Twin Childhood Computer Set with Preschool activities and the remaining funds for accessories and desk to accomidate the computer and its additional accessories, keyboard etc...

iStartSmart is a kid-friendly preschool computer, preloaded with early childhood software that scaffolds learning. It monitors child progress as children play, showing administrators and teachers exactly what each child knows, so they can make informed decisions about small and large group instruction.

All of the money I receive in donations will go directly to the students.


The Impact

Build School Readiness Skills

  • Fully engaged learning means results
  • Pinpoint exactly what each child knows
  • Scaffolded levels in 18 core skill areas
  • Progress data compiled at the individual, class, organization & district level
“The children can do everything themselves and with the random nature of the activities,they don’t get bored with this preschool computer!”

Risks & Challenges

I hope the biggest challenge will be which preschool computer to choose from!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    Donate, even just one dollar. It is less dissappointing to have everyone donating a dollar...than everyone not donating at all. That is how this works!!! Everyone who reads my campaign only needs to donate a small amount.

    • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
    • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

I'd like to pitch an awesome gift for an amazing kid and his wonderful mother.  The child's name is Nicholas, I used to date his mother, Casey.  At some point Casey and I went our separate ways, but afterward, she met the man who took her life. 

As a criminal justice major, I can’t help but learn about different disadvantages people face, nearly all since birth, and how they affect a person’s entire life.  Some disadvantages form inescapable categories.

Children without parents is one of those categories.

And who knows what troubles the future has lined up to multiply with yet more troubles because let's face it, reality either gets better or worse. 

What's worse, one day he could google how his mother died, and he will have every justification not to care about anything he does. 

And that's the crux of the problem.  So to this collection of crappy circumstances, we must give a collective "Nope."

There is one factor very likely to increase his odds of a better life; that factor is education. 

That education must come in the form of a bachelor's degree. 


So here I am, I'm crowd funding Nicholas a college education. 

And that's where you come in...


What I'm Asking

I've set the bar at 30,000, the cost of a basic college education. 

But this isn't all he would be getting. He'd get people backing him.  People rooting for him and his potential! 
Bottom-line: this kid is too cool to be defined by his circumstances, we want him to be his best in spite of them.

In addition to the college fund, I want to create a booklet full of encouraging messages from contributors, or anyone.  How outstanding would it be if he could read your message on a tough day somewhere down the line?

So please, email a brief message of encouragement.  
bagonzalez@spartan.northampton.edu
Jscalercio@spartan.northampton.edu

I know some of you might be thinking, "What if he drops out of school?"
Fair question. 

I know this: the way we treat people can help decide their actions, much like a self-fulfilling prophecy.  If people care, it could cause him to make really good decisions.  Knowing he can pay for college will give him a reason to work hard, and it will alleviate major strain from his life. 


The Impact

Your contribution might mean a totally different course in one human being's life.  This added opportunity could transform his life.  It could give him the means to be awesome when he is ready to be awesome. 

Just because we live in a first-world country, doesn't mean everyone in it has a first-world life.  Nicholas lost what is irreplaceable; his mother's support throughout his life.  We cannot remedy that, but we can take it upon ourselves to ensure he has the means to better himself through education.  In ten years Nicholas will be a man, and I want him to have the opportunity to learn, and pursue a career of his choice later in life, to help balance the loss he has taken early in life.




Risks and Challenges

I am undaunted by risks and challenges! 

Even though the greatest challenge lies within our country itself.

We’ve all heard people being skeptical of higher education.  We’ve heard stories from a friend of a friend saying, “Mike’s got his masters but he still can’t find a job, now he has to pan for gold in the river or some ridiculous job".

Has the time come to ditch education, and invest our energy on social media alone to become a professional twerker in the competitive world of give me attention? Does being intelligent mean lowering your expectations? 

No!  We just better information. 

Those starting at the lowest 20% of earners, (The poor) who never complete high school roughly have a 50% chance of being poor.  Forever.

That's like flipping a coin, and dealing with the result your entire life.

However, those with a bachelor’s degree gain an 84% chance of ditching poverty. 

And 20% of that 84% find their way to the top 20% of earners.  Awesome.

The source for these statistics come from http://www.brookings.edu/research/essays/2014/saving-horatio-alger#

So why then, if the numbers state education's value so definitely, is there so much controversy?  Why is there reason to think otherwise?

Simply stated, our system is very sick.  The United States is no longer very socially mobile, and that is the challenge of all challenges.  Of all the top earners in our country, 70% of them were born that way, just the way the poor are born poor.  And some intelligent people say, because of this, the United States is no longer the 'republic' it once was, it is now something called an 'oligarchy.'  Which sucks.  And its on us.

In the face of ugly realities, lets not lower our ambitions  or our attention span.  Got to find real ways to work hard.  Ditching education may seem right, but the truth is we need to aspire to better types of education. 


Other Ways to Help!

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help.
  • Spread the word and make some noise!  This is a cause to be excited about, together we can give someone an awesome gift!
  • Email a hopeful message!

The Account

The money lands in a simple, savings account for the child, who will be an adult in ten years.  None of it gets invested in any plan involving stocks, ect.  I remain separate from Nicolas' guardian so they cannot use the money for non-educational purposes.  There is no exact, tax-exempt, charitable classification I can put on the money, because it is for one individual.  So I expect I will have to pay taxes on it one time as earned income.   After taxes are settled, this money will be for the singular purpose of funding an education.  No other use for it will be permitted.    

A Personal Message 

I want to thank you awesome people in advance.  When I met Casey, she was coming out of a rough time, and she said I could take her number, but she's the type of person who needed help.
I want to keep my word by giving Nicholas a boost in life, even if I'm not really part of his life.  This is important, and personal to me.  And if this succeeds, I'd like to take on more issues similar to these.
story_txt:
Short Summary
I'd like to pitch an awesome gift for an amazing kid and his wonderful 
mother.  The child's name is Nicholas, I used to date his mother, 
Casey.  At some point Casey and I went our separate ways, but afterward,
 she met the man who took her life.  
As a criminal justice major, I can’t help but learn about different disadvantages people face, nearly all since birth, and how they
affect a person’s entire life.  Some disadvantages form inescapable categories.
Children without parents is
one of those categories.
And who knows what troubles the future has lined up to multiply with yet more troubles because let's face it, reality either gets better or worse.  
What's worse, one day he could google how his mother died, and he will have every justification not to care about anything he does.  And that's the crux of the problem.  So to this collection of crappy circumstances, we must give a collective "Nope."There is one factor very likely to increase his odds of a better life; that factor is education.  That education must come in the form of a bachelor's degree.  

So here I am, I'm crowd funding Nicholas a college education.  

And that's where you come in...

I've set the bar at 30,000, the cost of a basic college education.  But this isn't all he would be getting. story:
Varför en zombieöverlevnadsbok

Har du tänkt på hur du klara av ett zombieutbrott? Om zombierna höll på att ta över världen, hur länge skulle du överleva? Du är inte ensam. Du är en av många som fantiserat om vad som skulle hända om zombierna kom till ditt hem. Nu finns Zombieöverlevnad – din guide till apokalypsen som kan ge dig svar på några frågor och förmodligen väcka många andra. Boken är skriven av Herman Geijer som startade zombieöverlevnadskurser på ABF och är idag Sveriges mest kände zombieöverlevnadsexpert. 

Boken är den första zombieöverlevnadsguiden för svenska förhållanden, fylld med fakta, tips och mängder av pedagogiska illustrationer.


Det finns flera andra zombieöverlevnadsböcker ute på marknaden. Den mest kända är Max Brooks Zombie Survival Guide från 2003. Brooks klassiker har dock stora brister som överlevnadsbok. Där Brooks ägnar 35 sidor åt vapen ger Zombieöverlevnad din guide till apokalypsen dig en bild av hur samhället reagerar på kriser och katastrofer.


Där Brooks ägnar tio sidor åt strategier för strid under vatten med zombier beskriver Geijer hur människan påverkas psykologiskt och hur vi kan träna oss i krisberedskap. Boken är – som sagt – skriven utifrån svenska förhållanden.


Zombieöverlevnad är ett tvärvetenskapligt ämne. Det handlar om psykologi, medicin, överlevnadskunskap, filmveteskap, biologi, sociologi och MacGyverinspirerad problemlösning. Genom att studera verkliga katastrofer och kriser går det att hitta sätt att öka chanserna att överleva zombiekatastrofen. Kunskaperna går också att använda vid problem vi kan möta innan zombierna kommer.

Boken är rikligt illustrerad av Jimmy Wallin. Ta chansen att ge dina nära och kära större chanser att överleva zombiekatastrofen. Även om boken inte officiellt är årets julklapp, kommer du ha mer glädje av den än av bakmaskinen, spikmattan eller wokpannan.  

Backa boken och få den i din brevlåda innan jul – det är den perfekta julklappen.
Alla andra får vänta till början av nästa år då den inte går att köpa i butik förrän i januari 2015 (med undantag för eventuella specialsigneringar och nån "hemlig" releasefest (gilla oss på Facebook för mer info!)), så passa på – 2015 kan det vara försent...

Apart Förlag på Facebook: www.facebook.com/apartforlag
The Walking Dead (på svenska) på Facebook: www.facebook.com/twd.sv
Nej Tack Zombies på Facebook: www.facebook.com/zombieoverlevnad

Ni kan också följa oss på andra sociala medier:
Twitter: @nejtackzombies och @apartforlag
Instagram och Tumblr: @apartforlag


Backa boken och få ett personligt
zombieporträtt av Jimmy Wallin

Om du backar projektet har du möjlighet att bli en av de 25 lyckliga som blir avporträtterade av Jimmy Wallin som illustrerat hela boken.  Vill du inte ha ett på dig själv går det lika bra att få ett porträtt av din käresta, din svärmor eller ditt husdjur. Eller en zombievariant av din bröllopsbild. 

(Du mailar det foto du vill ha zombifierat till overlevnad@apartforlag.se efter att du valt den "perk" du vill ha)

Nedan ser ni fem exempel på zombieporträtt som han gjort till några förordskribenterna till våra utgåvor av The Walking Dead: 


Herman Geijer

Herman Geijer är Sveriges främsta zombieöverlevnadsexpert och står bakom bland annat ABF:s studie-cirkel Att överleva zombiekatastrofen, bloggen www.zombieoverlevnad.se, samt podcasten Swedish Zomcast.


Jimmy Wallin

Jimmy Wallin är bland annat serieskapare, illustratör och skräckfilmsfantast och har de senaste åren gjort tusentals zombieporträtt på mässor och workshops runt om i landet. Du kan se några av hans porträtt här till exempel här: www.facebook.com/apartforlag


Apart Förlag

Apart Förlag ger ut livsviktig litteratur som The Walking Dead, A Game of Thrones och Sherlock Holmes på svenska och samlar den svenska tecknareliten i titlar som Ordningen upprätthålls alltid – det vill säga böcker de själva vill läsa men som inte gick att få tag på. Tidigare i höstas gav de ut ”en bilderbok från helvetet”* där läsaren får följa en SS-dolk från trettiotalets Berlin till tvåtusentalets Borås. Genom århundradet kommer den att ägas av bland annat black metal-musiker, samlare, ockultister och en försupen brevbärare. Boken, som är skriven av Pär Thörn och illustrerad av  skräcktecknaren Lars Krantz, kunde ges ut efter en lyckad crowdfunding här på indiegogo. Mer info:  www.apartforlag.se/SS-dolken.



*citatet är hämtat från seriebibliotekariens recension som ni kan läsa här:
http://www.seriebibliotekarien.com/2014/10/agan...

story:
Hello,

 My name is Lauren Carroll and I was a funeral director for 5 years. In that time I met many families and learned many things about death and dying and the way we celebrate that life in the American Culture. During that time I discovered some families wanted MORE. They needed more time, more ceremony, and a different setting than a church or funeral home. After I left the industry(because that's what it is) I became passionate about Home Funerals. There is a sacred tradition that has been lost in time. Most people don't even know that a home funeral is an option, that you CAN care for your own loved ones at HOME. 


 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We are looking for $15,000 to get started. This money will fund the costs to print  educational materials, home care funeral products ("Green" Caskets and Burial Shrouds), and enough money to serve 10 families who cannot afford the minimal costs associated with a  home funeral INCLUDING the burial or cremation.

 Once our goals are met. We will begin additional Fundraisers to raise money to purchase the forest land to build the ECO-CEMETERY. Where families will be able to burial their loved ones in the most natural and green settings. No chemicals, no metals polluting our Earth!


 As a contributor you can sign up for monthly emails and be included in future fundraising events including death cafes, and  educational seminars. You will also  be able to read about families we have served and see their stories through photos.


The Impact

 

A Traditional funeral which includes embalming, caskets, and burials cost the average american $7,500. You can find more facts about the costs of funerals in America here.http://nfda.org/about-funeral-service-/trends-and-statistics.html Not only is that a HUGE financial burden during a time of loss and grief but  we are putting the embalming fluid and heavy metals used in caskets directly into the EARTH! Embalmers wear protective gear when using these chemicals because of the toxicity of embalming fluid so why are we putting it into the ground to be reabsorbed into our water and soil???

 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money please share this! Email it to friends, share it on Facebook or twitter...whatever you can do! Just talking about the movement of Home Funerals and Green Burials helps!

story:
GOOD SAMARITAN VISION ORPHANAGE AND SCHOOL

Hi there, we need your help. Our School’s 20 year old minibus has broken down and it will cost $582 (£375, €427) to fix. We use the bus for everything; collecting food supplies, taking children to hospital and getting the older pupils to the nearest senior school.

If you can make a donation we would be delighted. You can use Visa and Mastercard here or to make a PAYPAL donation use the button below.

WHAT IS GOOD SAMARITAN VISION?
Good Samaritan Vision started life as a rescue centre for destitute and trafficked children and has evolved into an orphanage and school for Kenyan children from 0 – 16.

WHERE IS IT?
GSV Orphanage is 5 kms from the nearest town of Kilifi on the North Kenyan coast. It is a two hour drive from Kenya’s second city Mombassa.

FUNDING
GSV aims to be a self sustaining community project. It raises money by leading nature walks for tourists. But in recent years (owing to civil unrest and the global recession) tourist numbers have declined. This has lead to a substantial fall in income. Places like GSV survive on such meagre resources that even a relatively small sum like $600 is impossible to find – unless it is diverted from the food budget.

PLEASE MAKE A DONATION NO MATTER HOW SMALL TO HELP THE CHILDREN OF GOOD SAMARITAN VISION CONTINUE TO EDUCATE THEMSELVES OUT OF POVERTY. THANK YOU.

story:
Job Ninja

My name is Ernie.  I've been a high school guidance counselor for nine years.  I constantly have students coming to my office asking me where they can find a job.  I tell them to go to Monster.com or Careerbuilder but apparently college and high school students don't like those sites.

On the other side, independent business owners don't have the budgets to use the previously mentioned sites so they are left with sticking jobs listings in the paper or Craigslist.  

I am building a website that will be primarily designed for student job seekers and independent employers.

We already have a site up with and running but we need your help to further develop it.  As of now, employers can post jobs and collect resumes online.  

Job seekers can set up an account and apply to jobs.  Plus jobs are highlighted in different colors to signify if they are part-time, full-time, volunteer, etc.  This helps students sift through the jobs faster while still giving the local employers a one stop shop for their needs.

Job Ninja provides a unique place for full-time students to find part-time jobs.  It also levels the playing field for independent businesses who want to add online resume collection to their hiring process.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $20,000.

Here's where the money will go:  Legal fees, Promotional materials, further site development, marketing. 

In the site development category, we want to provide as much value as possible to employers.  So with some of the money we raise, we will be adding in assessments and activities for job seekers to complete to raise their Ninja Ranking.  When they apply to jobs, employers will see who the applicants are with the most desire.

We have one of the coolest logos around.  The more you contribute, the more stuff you get with our logo on it.  There are stickers, t-shirts, coffee mugs, pens, and hats.

Our employer level contributions include packages that will let you use our service for an extended period of time with no charge.

If we don't reach our goal, our funds will go to the item of biggest need.  In our case, the first priority is taking care of legal fees.  

The Impact

Your contribution is going to help give students all over the United States a place to find jobs.  And it is going to give independent employers a cost-effective way to find better employees and a more convenient way to collect applications.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, you can always contribute a little time or PR.  Tell your friends about Job Ninja.  If you know someone who runs a business, tell them to give us a try.  Spreading the word will help us a great deal too!

Thanks!
story_txt:
Job Ninja
My name is Ernie.  I've been a high school guidance counselor for nine years.  I constantly have students coming to my office asking me where they can find a job.  I tell them to go to Monster.com or Careerbuilder but apparently college and high school students don't like those sites.
On the other side, independent business owners don't have the budgets to use the previously mentioned sites so they are left with sticking jobs listings in the paper or Craigslist.  
I am building a website that will be primarily designed for student job seekers and independent employers.
We already have a site up with and running but we need your help to further develop it.  As of now, employers can post jobs and collect resumes online.  
Job seekers can set up an account and apply to jobs.  Plus jobs are highlighted in different colors to signify if they are part-time, full-time, volunteer, etc.  This helps students sift through the jobs faster while still giving the local employers a one stop shop for their needs.
Job Ninja provides a unique place for full-time students to find part-time jobs.  It also levels the playing field for independent businesses who want to add online resume collection to their hiring process.
 


What We Need & What You Get
We need $20,000.
Here's where the money will go:  Legal fees, Promotional materials, further site development, marketing. 
In the site development category, we want to provide as much value as possible to employers.  So with some of the money we raise, we will be adding in assessments and activities for job seekers to complete to raise their Ninja Ranking.  When they apply to jobs, employers will see who the applicants are with the most desire.
We have one of the coolest logos around.  The more you contribute, the more stuff you get with our logo on it.  There are stickers, t-shirts, coffee mugs, pens, and hats.
Our employer level contributions include packages that will let you use our service for an extended period of time with no charge.
If we don't reach our goal, our funds will go to the item of biggest need.  In our case, the first priority is taking care of legal fees.  


The Impact
Your contribution is going to help give students all over the United States a place to find jobs.  And it is going to give independent employers a cost-effective way to find better employees and a more convenient way to collect applications.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute money, you can always contribute a little time or PR.  Tell your friends about Job Ninja.  If you know someone who runs a business, tell them to give us a try.  Spreading the word will help us a great deal too!
Thanks!

story:
Kurzbeschreibung

Mein Name ist Romina Spasiano, ich bin 14 Jahre alt, gehe in die 9.Klasse eines Gymnasiums und mein größter Traum ist es, ein Jahr in Irland zu verbringen.
Ich wohne bei meiner Mutter, habe aber auch ein gutes Verhältnis zu meinem Vater. Meine Schwester Sarah ist derzeit in Afrika, meine Schwester Anna fängt eine Ausbildung an und mein Zwillingsbruder Johnny und ich gehen noch zur Schule, auf ein Gymnasium in die gleiche Klasse. Wir lernen beide Italienisch in der Schule, da unser Vater Italiener ist. 
Meine Hobbys sind vor allem singen und Klavier spielen. Musik prägt mich und ist für mich wie eine zweite Welt. Außerdem liebe ich Sport. Ich habe 8 Jahre lang geturnt und ein Jahr lang getanzt. Eine große Leidenschaft von mir ist das Theater und Schauspiel. Ich habe nicht viele Erfahrungen dabei, aber ich liebe es und das ist das wichtigste an Hobbys.
Das Auslandsjahr ist für mich sehr wichtig, da ich mir das schon sehr lange Wünsche und ich einfach mal rauskommen will. Ich möchte die Welt sehen und neue Dinge entdecken, Menschen aus der ganzen Welt kennen lernen und Freunde fürs Leben finden! Das sind die Dinge die mich antreiben und mir Mut machen, es trotzdem zu versuchen, auch wenn ich es am Ende wegen Geldmangels doch nicht schaffen kann.
Sie werden mir dabei helfen, mein Auslandsjahr zu finanzieren, um mir die Chance zu geben, mich selbst zu entwickeln und meine Ziele zu erreichen.

Was wir brauchen & Was man bekommt

Weil ich das nicht selbst finanzieren und meine Familie mich auch nicht stemmen kann, habe ich mich schon für ein Stipendium beworben und dafür ein Lied geschrieben, da mir Musik sehr wichtig ist. Auch wenn ich das Stipendium bekommen sollte, brauche ich immer noch 4000-5000€.
Leider kann ich ihnen kein Geld zurückgeben, da ich nur Schülerin bin. Dafür werde ich, wenn ich denn gehen kann, einen Blog veröffentlichen werde und sie dort nachlesen können, was ich mit dem Geld anstelle.
Wenn ich mein Ziel nicht erreichen kann, wird das Geld vorerst für meine Zukunft angelegt, denn vielleicht werde ich dann im nächsten Jahr nach Irland aufbrechen.

Die Auswirkung

Ich bin für ihre Spende besonders geeignet, weil ich mich schon lange sozial engagiere. Meist aber nur in meiner Schule, was auch ziemlich viel zu ist. 
Im Schuljahr 2011/12 war ich Unterstufensprecherin und damit im Schülersprecherteam. Seit der 5.Klasse bin ich in der SMV (Schülermitverantwortung) vertreten.
Ich bin ausgebildete Streitschlichterin, Moderatorin unseres Schülerradios, war und werde wieder im Debating-Team sein, singe im Schulchor und bin gerade wieder zur Klassensprecherin gewählt worden. 
Dieses Jahr habe ich mich bei der "72h-Aktion" der katholischen Gemeinde beteiligt. Außerdem habe ich dort auch kurze Zeit die "Gruppenstunde" auf eigene Faust geleitet, da sich kein Erwachsener gefunden hatte.
Ich werde Deutschland in Irland vertreten und dies mit meinen Referenz auch gut meistern können.

Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

Verbreiten Sie meine Seite und mein Anliegen doch, wenn Sie selbst nichts tun können. Einfach auf Facebook, Twitter, usw. teilen und auch so an Familie, Verwandte, Bekannte, Freunde, Kollegen, usw. weitersagen. Man kann dafür übrigens auch direkt ein Tool von Indiegogo benutzen.
Sie helfen damit einem Menschen sein Ziel zu erreichen!
Danke für alles was Sie für mich tun!

story:
Summary

Crayon Box Labs is a group of students from around the Bay Area in California. We have two apps on the market, and we’ve won Best in State for the 2012 Verizon Innovative App Challenge. Our main interest is making apps and games, and our dream is to become a videogame company.


We want to attend a 48 hour long programming competition (called a ‘hackathon’) at Princeton University in New Jersey. Attending this competition will be pivotal moment in our little company, and it’ll bring us closer to making awesome games for the world to enjoy! Our overall goal is $4,000 to cover the travel expenses for the entire group, as well as to buy equipment (such as microcontrollers and breakout boards) for use during the competition as well as future app development.


Your help will be a huge role in our journey. Ready to help an aspiring, entrepreneurial group of young tech-savvy students reach their dreams? To show our gratitude, we have an array of perks and gifts to offer back to all those who support us.

Who we are: Crayon Box Labs


We are Crayon Box Labs, a group of graphic artists, programmers, musicians and writers dedicated to creating novel and entertaining apps. We’re a family comprised of high school students with a few of college freshmen.

http://www.crayonboxlabs.com/


I am the President and one of the original founders of this humble organization. My name is Ahsan Zahid. I’ve had a deep connection and love for computers since I was little. I started programming at 11, and I got my first professional Cisco Certification at age 13, another at 14, and a third at 17.


Here’s an article that talks a little bit more about who I am and my aspirations as a leader and techie:

http://www.mercurynews.com/milpitas/ci_14420333
http://sidengo.com/ahsanzahid


Our company’s humble origins started with me and two friends just hanging out in the biology classroom of our high school. Our little group soon grew and we all began to realize that we wanted to turn our thoughts and ideas into reality.We also realized our diverse and individual backgrounds had all the makings of a potential start-up. Soon little pet projects turned into full-fledged apps and here we are now.

What we do: Make games and apps!

We call ourselves Crayon Box Labs! Our team as of now is comprised of 12 people, each handling multiple roles, covering programming, graphics, music, storywriting, character design, level design, voiceovers, public relations, and marketing.


Together, we launched our first two apps to the Google Play Store and the SlideMe Market:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/developer?id=Crayon+Box+Labs
http://slideme.org/user/zerova0


`They have, collectively across markets, over 4,000 downloads. In 2012, we entered the Verizon Innovative App Challenge, a mobile application design competition, and won Best in State in California for our concept of a school navigation app.


Our dream is to someday start an actual video game company, working together to make awesome games for a variety of platforms. To get there though, we’re trying to gain experience by working on projects and actually making things!

What we need: YOUR support at HackPrinceton

‘Hackathons’, a combination of ‘hack’ and ‘marathon’, is exactly what it sounds like: a hacking marathon! This is where teams of coders, designers, artists, and engineers come together and within a specific time limit, they work on creating a new app, a new game, a new software… The possibilities are endless! At the end of the designing and hacking frenzy, each team demos its project, and prizes are awarded.

One such renowned competition is HackPrinceton, which will take place at Princeton University, on the weekend of November 8.

We have the determination and the drive to get there but unfortunately, we lack the funds. For us to be able to get there and represent the good Bay Area name in tech development, we need more help. We’re all students, and we need you to help us in regards to travel expenses and equipment expenses. Our overall goal is $4,000 to cover the flight tickets from California to New Jersey as well as some software and hardware we need for the competition.

The Impact:

All of the technology and modern conveniences we enjoy now such as our smartphones even down to the innovative and helpful little apps all started somewhere. They started with people like us: people who dared to dream, people who dared to put themselves out there and seek the resources they needed to get started. You be can part of this journey to propel innovation and creativity forward into a new age. This competition will give our group the much needed access to creative new ideas as we network with other teams across the country and help develop our own skills as we challenge ourselves to create professional, unique, and amazing new apps, games, software within a limited timeframe. Think of us as an investment; sponsoring our education now as individuals increases what we can contribute to society as adults.  We’re asking you not to support a group of teenagers, we’re asking you to support the future.

Other Ways to Help: Spread the word!

If you’re unable to donate due to financial reasons, there’s another way you can help: spread the word! Share the link to this campaign to everyone you know, via Facebook, Twitter, G+, email, SMS, telegraph, or messenger pigeon! The more people that know, the more support we can get, and the more successful our journey will be!

story:
About Me! I Wanna Be A Midwife!

My name is Deborah.  I have a nursing background and I am a certified lactation counselor.  I have worked as a WIC Peer Counselor for the last three years and as a birth assistant for the last year.  My journey to becoming a midwife started seven years ago with the birth of my first son.  I fell on love with the field and began my journey as a CNA in the hospital.  My heart is for women to have a choice in how they want to birth and how they want to feed their baby.  Birth is a very personal and sacred experience.  I plan to support women emotionally and physically throughout their labor.  I want to encourage birth to be a family event, helping to encompass and support the family through the transition and addition of their beloved baby.  Having contributors will help me financially afford to attend school and clinical throughout my educational experience.  This in turn will help me to be focused on the care of my clients and not worried about the financial aspect of my life.

The Funds!

Here is the breakdown!

  • I am trying to raise 1,500 for the next semester. This will cover food, and accommodations for the next semester as well as gas for going to my preceptor site while on call.  I will also be attending prenatal and postpartum visits in the birth center and in the community.  I commute 3 1/2 hours away, which is the closest MECA accredited school in my area, and I have to commute an hour away for my clinical preceptor site.  All funds will used towards school expenses.

Your investment will:

  • Provide an excellent education for midwifery student.
  • Equip the midwifery student with the skills to address prenatal, postpartum care along with education about breastfeeding, sexually transmitted disease, and sexual assault
  • Teach communication with the mother and the family. Become a resource in the community that helps to empower women and give them a voice throughout their birthing experience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some  just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Feel free to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
I'm Valencia, a young, energetic, young professional chasing my dreams which include traveling the world and learning about other peoples' way of life. I have been given the opportunity of a lifetime: To work as an intern at the Smithsonian's Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage.

The catch: The internship is unpaid and I found out about it a month before I have to leave. Please help me pay for my trip and expenses. Even a dollar would make a huge difference. 

Your funding will help me pay some start off cost of living like food, transportation, toiletries, and cleaning items.

Funding this project will help me get the training I need to one day start a cultural center in Milwaukee, Wisconsin that will be a place where youth can study, play music, learn to dance, view film screenings, and learn about their culture in the library. This is step one.

As energetic, passionate people ready for change and action, let's support one another!

Please share with friends!

story:
Short Summary

Infusionarts is a UK based organisation run by Shirley Beth Newbery. Infusionarts works in both the UK, Africa and most recently America. It runs community based arts courses, workshops and film projects. In Africa Shirley Beth raises money for micro projects, and individuals in need. Her small but trusted network of contacts there ensures that her not-for-profit activities make a significant difference for those she helps. In 2009 for example infusionarts raised the $800 needed to pay for an operation for a Maasai lady with a large goiter condition.

              

The operation led to a full recovery and her reintegration into her community. Looking forward to 2014, infusionarts is raising money to fund schooling for six children in Northern Tanzania. Three at primary level, and three at secondary level. This will significantly enhance the lives of those six children and their families, and increase their chances of further education and a hopeful future. A future in which educated young people in Africa see their developing countries grow stronger, becoming self-sufficient and prosperous.

"I have been to villages in Tanzania many times and I have met families where schooling has been introduced. Many families live at a subsistence level and cannot afford the fees or school uniform, even though they are very low by Western standards. The hope for the family's future seems to shine brighter when their children are attending school. The children I have met are keen to learn and would take pride in their place at a school". Your money will help these children and their families by giving them hope for a brighter future. Some may be attending school for the first time,others may need help to continue with their education, with the hope of eventually going on to college or university and a career.

Imagine having to tell your own children that they will have to stay at home because you cannot afford to send them to school. With small campaigns like this we can make a huge difference to the lives of some children!      

What We Need & What You Get.

For this project we need to raise £6,000. No longer is our wonderful artist in need of funds, a great friend has provided that and arranged it already, ! yeah! So why send an artist to climb a mountain? Well, its simply to help raise more money ! Gregory Wellman, currently featured on Sky Arts Portrait Artist of the year Award, is climbing Kilimanjaro in February 2014 to help gain interest and increased publicity for this great project. Individuals get a chance to own a great piece of art ,a Signed Limited Print by Gregory. Businesses and individuals can have their company logo shown on top the highest free standing mountain in the world for a much appreciated $1000!

You get a photo and update on the children being sponsored, and can request further information throughout the year.

Due to infusionarts African contacts we can keep costs low. What ever we get will pay for these children so if we don't reach the goal, all will go to them and you will be sent confirmation on those fortunate ones to have been given this opportunity.

All money raised will now go to the children. The climb has been sorted thanks to a wonderful company we have links with!  So Approx costs: Kilimanjaro climb $2,000. (includes all operator and National Park Fees)  


Flight approx $1,000. (I will pay for all guide and porter tips, and all other of my trip and all other expenses) All money from above goes to the kids in need! yeah... that means we can now give to more . thank you, thank you, thank you! 

Each disadvantaged child from the camp Moses site costs $50 per month for shelther, food and schooling, and yes thats $600 per year. 

To support a Maasai child's schooling is just $400 per year. We want enough for six children to benefit. If possible- the more the better! That is our goal for 2014.

infusionarts go to our projects in Africa


The Impact- can help many in the future!

We want to help disadvantaged children who for a variety of reasons have no family who can care for them. They are at risk of becoming street children, these are Orphaned from Lohada. where children can be helped! They will have housing, food and water with a change to leave and get work , provide for their own families and community. We also want to help three Maasai children who are from need in our ever changing world. With less and less land and no education what do these young people have? Helping a child to get educated helps their families, one less to feed during the day, a short term, but the longer vision is simply that in turn families and then the community are helped. Educated children become employable young adults, and assist their families financially. We believe helping people when they need it, helping people to support themselves and to build a sustainable future. 

Please get in touch via the infusionarts website if you would like further information.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you cannot contribute financially, you can still help! Share this appeal on social media like Facebook, Twitter, Google+ etc. 

    We would value your support in any way, even just talking to people you know and pointing them in the right direction! 

    Let your compassion touch the life of a child and make a whole family smile

    And that’s all there is to it. Let your compassion touch a person today and bring a smile!
story_txt:
Short Summary


Infusionarts is
a UK based organisation run by Shirley Beth Newbery. Infusionarts works in both
the UK, Africa and most recently America. It runs community based arts courses,
workshops and film projects. In Africa Shirley Beth raises money for micro
projects, and individuals in need. Her small but trusted network of contacts
there ensures that her not-for-profit activities make a significant difference
for those she helps. In 2009 for example infusionarts raised the $800 needed to
pay for an operation for a Maasai lady with a large goiter condition. 
              

The
operation led to a full recovery and her reintegration into her community.
Looking forward to 2014, infusionarts is raising money to fund schooling for
six children in Northern Tanzania. Three at primary level, and three at
secondary level. This will significantly enhance the lives of those six
children and their families, and increase their chances of further education
and a hopeful future. A future in which educated young people in Africa see their
developing countries grow stronger, becoming self-sufficient and prosperous.
"I have been to
villages in Tanzania many times and I have met families where schooling has
been introduced. Many families live at a subsistence level and cannot afford
the fees or school uniform, even though they are very low by Western standards.
The hope for the family's future seems to shine brighter when their children
are attending school. The children I have met are keen to learn and would take pride
in their place at a school". Your money will help these children and their
families by giving them hope for a brighter future. Some may be attending
school for the first time,others may need help to continue with their
education, with the hope of eventually going on to college or university and a
career.
Imagine having to
tell your own children that they will have to stay at home because you cannot
afford to send them to school. With small campaigns like this we can make a
huge difference to the lives of some children!      

What We Need & What You Get.

For this project
we need to raise £6,000. No longer is our wonderful artist in need of funds, a great friend has provided that and arranged it already, ! yeah! So why send an artist to climb a mountain? Well, its simply to help
raise more money ! Gregory Wellman, currently featured on Sky Arts Portrait Artist of the year Award, is climbing Kilimanjaro in February 2014 to help gain interest and increased publicity for this great project. Individuals get a chance to own a great piece of art ,a Signed Limited Print by Gregory. Businesses and individuals can have their company
logo shown on top the highest free standing mountain in the world for a much
appreciated $1000!
You get a photo
and update on the children being sponsored, and can request further information
throughout the year.
Due to
infusionarts African contacts we can keep costs low. What ever we get will pay for these children so if we don't reach the goal, all will go to them and you will be sent confirmation on those fortunate ones to have been given this opportunity.
All money raised will now go to the children. The climb has been sorted thanks to a wonderful company we have links with!  So Approx costs: Kilimanjaro
climb $2,000. (includes all operator and National Park Fees)  

Flight approx $1,000. (I will pay for all guide and porter tips,
and all other of my trip and all other expenses) All money from above goes to the kids in need! yeah... that means we can now give to more . thank you, thank you, thank you! 
Each disadvantaged child from the
camp Moses site costs $50 per month for shelther, food and schooling, and yes
thats $600 per year. 
To support a Maasai child's schooling is just $400 per year. We want enough
for six children to benefit. If possible- the more the better! That is our goal for 2014.
infusionarts go to our projects in Africa

We want to help
disadvantaged children who for a variety of reasons have no family who can care
for them. They are at risk of becoming street children, these are Orphaned from Lohada. where children can be helped! They will have housing, food and water with a change to leave and get work , provide for their own families and community. and bring a smile!

story:
Our friend is a senior disabled single woman being harassed, bullied and sued by her HOA (Home Owners Association).

We desperately need some help to put a stop to this discriminating situation. 

Since recently moving out to her 5-acre property in the Country, to enjoy her retirement while fishing and enjoying nature, she is being harassed, bullied and sued by her HOA, for installing three outdoor security lights on her horseshoe shaped driveway on her corner property.  These lights do not shine onto the community/public roads or onto other properties!  Two of the lights were installed by the electric company and are 23’ and 26’ high with Int'l. dark sky compliant with 250w illumination with amber bulbs and the third light is on a 17’ pole with a dusk to dawn 65w bulb, that shines downwards.

Let me share a little about my friend, so you will know how she got into this predicament. Four and half years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer. After the chemotherapy and the radiation treatments she returned to work and was laid off. She has always prided herself in working hard to make a living, but the cancer took its toll. We are blessed that she survived the disease and the treatments, yet unfortunately, she is not the same person physically. She sold her home in the city, so she could move to the country, to live out her retirement on her disability income and do what she enjoys doing most: fishing, being outdoors and watching wildlife, especially feeding the deer on her property.

She has a modest home on 5-acres and installed outdoor lighting for her safety, security and enjoyment of the wildlife. Three months after moving into her country home, her HOA advised her that she was in violation of the deed restrictions over the outdoor lighting. However, none of us could find one restriction addressing outdoor lighting. She has asked repeatedly for the HOA to tell her what article in the deed restrictions addresses outdoor lighting. They could not answer her question and quickly scolded her like a child, saying the Board had decided that she had enough lights and promptly dismissed her. She has tried on several occasions to resolve this matter unsuccessfully. Not being able to tie her outdoor lighting to any other restriction, the HOA decided to use the nuisance article, thereby declaring it a nuisance and filed a temporary injunction against her. At that hearing she did not have legal counsel and the HOA won. Now, the HOA has filed for a permanent injunction, wanting her to turn off these three lights and stating that anyone who should ever own this property, (including herself, her heirs, friends, family and associates) could never have this outdoor lights. They want her her live in total darkness and they are now suing her for their legal fees and to get this temporary injunction made into a permanent ruling. Instead of living out the rest of her life doing the simple things on her country property, she is fighting for her rights against being harassed, abused, bullied and sued by her HOA.  She does not deserve this treatment.  She is a wonderful, kind and caring woman that is always helping others.

I am asking you to help her hire an HOA attorney.  She is not a lawyer and cannot represent herself.  Since she lives on a fixed income, the only way for her to pursue this legal route and stop this harassment and bullying tactics from the HOA, is to hire an attorney to represent her.  We have been advised it could cost in the neighborhood of $35,000.00 - $50,000.00 to fight this. She has exhausted all of her menial savings and now her family, friends and neighbors, have started a fund to enable her to put a stop to this harassment, bullying and abuse.  To date, we have raised $2100.00 and yet we need so much more!

PLEASE contribute to this campaign. Help us spread the word and refer your friends, family and co-workers to this web site.  She needs all of our help so she can live out her life in peace.  By helping her, we can stop this HOA from bullying and abusing other senior disabled single women and the many other people being abused by their HOA’s.  THANK YOU.

story:
If You Believe in the 'Same Old' Educational Model This Page is Not For You

 

 

What We’re About:

A Movement to Heal and Reform the Educational System

In early May 2013 High School Student Jeff Bliss made national headlines on hundreds of Media Outlets and blogs when a video of him expressing his dissatisfaction with the educational system hit the web, securing millions of views. Our goal is to turn his 15 minutes of fame into a foundation for a lifetime of success, while at the same time addressing fundamental issues in our educational system. That’s why we're creating a special fund to assist Jeff, the school; and provide students and teachers across the globe with more effective learning tools in what we call Operation Education Disruption.

 

To Put It Simply We're Trying To Do 3 Things

1.) Give this young man a future!!!!

How many 18 year olds have that kind of perspective? He's a victim a system that doesn't understand him, and doesn't care to. He needs to be provided with the oppurtunity to pursue higher learning outside the public school systems.

       

2.) Transform the classroom to a 21st century model.

Operation Education Disruption Consists of Three Parts

Securing a Future for Jeff, Helping His School, and Healing the Situation by Creating New Methods of Bridging the Gap Between Students and Teachers

 

Part One

Jeff’s Future

Jeff Bliss’ statements that day were a call to arms, and hit the web like wildfire. Why? Because Jeff is not alone in his experience. There’s a reason why the video of a student disobeying a teacher in class went viral and was received with such resounding approval. Indeed, millions of students in our public school systems have faced similar, if not the exact same problems. Jeff said something that day that needed to be said; and right now, at this very moment; there is a lot of momentum behind his actions. It would be a shame to let this momentum fade, diminish, or worse yet,die. Instead we can use this moment to provide Jeff Bliss with a chance to make a difference and reshape the future of education. We plan on helping Jeff get a college education or training of his choosing and provide him with an opportunity of future success. He’s a brave and daring young man who already has a great sense of himself and can make great contributions to society if given the opportunity.

We propose the creation of a special fund to assist Jeff, the school, and a dedicated group of students, educators, technologists, and specialists, aptly named “Operation Education Disruption.”

Part Two

Helping the School

While Jeff’s school supposedly seems like the obvious butt of the joke here; we hope to reconcile this.  We recognize the issue doesn’t lie with this school alone, but is part of a systemic issue that most public schools face. This one video does not display the school’s ability to educate its students, it only highlights one particular problem in one particular classroom.

We were highly impressed by the superintendent’s response to the event, during a time of such widespread scrutiny. In a blog he left on the school’s website the superintendent said, “People around the world have seen an articulate Duncanville High School student express his opinion about wanting to be engaged in his education. The real story here is the message.” He continued to say, “The traditional classroom where desks are in straight rows, teachers stand and lecture, and students quietly copy notes has to evolve.”

While studying the educational model of this school, we discovered it’s actually quite unique (check them out http://www.duncanvilleisdnews.org/?p=4056).

This will be a collaborative effort and 1/3 of the proceeds will go to the Duncanville school district to personally address this problem.  Duncanville, like most schools, is forced to follow a set of bureaucratic rules that don’t allow them educational freedom that is needed to teach students in a changing world. It’s unfair to scapegoat them. We'd rather provide them with additional resources to make learning better for not only Jeff, but all of his classmates.

Part Three

 Addressing How We Learn

This needs to be important to all of us. Why?  Because as Jeff said about the educational system in the video, “This is the future of this nation.” As we get deeper into the age of the internet it seems foolish for classrooms to be solely based on an archaic lecture model developed in the 16th century. We need to provide schools with better and more interactive models of teaching their students.

The remaining funds from this program go to Operation Classroom Disruption; a program for the creation of, and collaboration with comprehensive online learning communities in public schools to bridge the gap between student and teachers. With the right tools we can make learning the joyous experience it deserves to be. We believe educational models like Khan Academy, Udacity, and Coursera ( www.khanacademy.org, www.udacity.com, www.coursera.org) are the way of the future, and their techniques should be implemented in our public schools.

What happened in that class was a display of a disconnect between students and teachers. New technologies will help to bridge that gap and make learning the joyous process it deserves to be. There’s a reason we rank we rank so poorly in education against competing nations, because we are stuck teaching the model of yesteryear.If we don’t adapt quickly, America will not only fall further behind in education; but, worse yet, we place ourselves in the inevitable position of losing our wealth as a nation.

 

What We Need

We need a minimum of $30,000 to launch this project, and with millions of video hits, I believe that this is an attainable goal.  However, we believe in reaching for the stars. We could make a much more substantial impact with 100,000 dollars, and really cause some disruption to the educational system.

 

What If You Have No Money to Donate, But Still Believe in What We’re Doing?

If you have no money to contribute, but still believe in what we’re doing, you can help us by getting the word out to everybody you know. You can post links of Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and other social media sites, email your friends, family, and most importantly contact mainstream media outlets, especially those outlets that have already covered the story before. Even if you don’t donate a dime there’s a lot you can do to help us out, and if you believe that education needs to be reformed, this a great way to do it. If you have ideas of your own on how to change education for the 21st century take this as a call to arms and pursue your own ideas. I want to see education change for the better; because as Jeff pointed out that day, ignorance is not bliss.

story:
About Myself

For those who don't already know me, my name is Michael Cunningham. I'm currently a Junior at Biola University studying Cinema & Media Arts.

I grew up on little. I was raised by a single mom in multiple living situations ranging from small apartments, to homeless shelters, motels and the occasional night in a car. The primary source of income was through child support and disability checks. I have five half-siblings who did not consistently live with my mom and I. I grew up like any other kid, going to school and playing with friends. The only difference between us was our parents’ income and marital status.

I wasn’t approached with the concept of college until 8th grade when we were talking about taking high school classes and how we would approach college the same way in high school. At this point I had moved from Bakersfield to Tustin and was getting used to the greater degree of difference in income between myself and everyone else around me. I never imagined myself going to college because it wasn’t a topic that was ever brought up at home.

Junior year was when most of my peers started looking at different colleges, it wasn’t until 3 months into my senior year that I was encouraged by my high school counselor to look into going to college.

I had become a Christian my junior year\]\and was eager to learn more about what my faith was about. The school that God lead me to was Biola. It was the only school I applied to, and I got accepted. It was a school that I could never have imagined being able to pay for, but God provided grants, scholarships and loans that covered the costs of attendance.

I’ve seen God’s grace transform the worst of sinners into a bumbling saint. I’ve seen His provision come through friends and family. In the unexplainable generosity of those who see a potential in me that I, at times, find hard to see.

About the trip

I'm at Biola on the bases of grace and grit. It’s the grace of God that brought me to an excellent institution and the grit required of me to do well in my studies.

Before I graduate in the fall of 2014, I have three amazing opportunities to take part in this year.

  • The first is to help make a feature length film in Jakarta, Indonesia from June 18th to July 17th.
  • The second is to make a short documentary in a smaller village in Indonesia after the feature film. We will be documenting their culture and teaching English.  
  • The third is the opportunity to study abroad in London during my fall semester at Roehampton University.

These different opportunities each have a unique outcome.

  • Indonesia will give me the opportunity play a part in telling a unique story through film. It will also expose myself and others to a different culture and language which will broaden my understanding of the way others think and relate to each other.
  • London will be an opportunity for me to interact with people that attend Roehampton University from around the world while traveling and studying the history of Europe and their style of filmmaking.

Both opportunities will expose me to different cultures, religions and worldviews that will allow me to better relate and work with those who don't share the same beliefs and cultural tendencies that I have. 

By helping to fund me, you will not only be helping to produce a movie, but you will also be helping me learn how to better listen to and tell stories of people around the world. 

What is needed

$8000 will fully fund my travel costs and room and board in Indonesia and London.

$2,000 of this will go toward the flight cost to Jakarta and Sulawesi, Indonesia. $300 will be going towards travel expenses in these areas. 

$5,000 will be going towards the travel cost to and from London along with the cost of living at the school from September to December. $1,000 will be going towards the cost of food and any other travel expenses.

What I have to offer to you? Myself. That is, showing you what I do during my time in these places through a short documentary, us getting to know each other on a more personal level through a skype conversation or letters, you receiving a canvas printing of any of my photography that I take during my time overseas, etc.

If I shouldn't raise the full $8,000, the funds will still help me go on these trips. If I raise enough for the flight costs to Indonesia and London and rooming in London, then I will at least be able to take part in both programs and figure out the food situation when I get there. 

The Impact

My hope is that these trips wouldn't just be about school or film-making. I desire to express the same love and hope that I've found in Jesus to whomever I meet on these trips. After all, this hope gave me a reason to pursue a college education in the first place.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate, there is still a way to help! You can...

1. Share my campaign with friends or family that might be able to help

2. Refer me to anyone you may know who could use high quality portraits done at a low cost between now and my trip dates. 

3. Refer me to anyone who could pay me to do miscellaneous chores  around their house between now and my trip dates. 

4. Pray for provision. 

Thank You for taking the time to learn a little bit more about myself and my campaign.

I had become a Christian my junior year\]\and was eager to learn more about what my faith was about. The school that God lead me to was Biola. It was the only school I applied to, and I got accepted.
