I’ve seen God’s grace transform the worst of sinners into a bumbling saint. I’ve seen His provision come through friends and family. In the unexplainable generosity of those who see a potential in me that I, at times, find hard to see.
About the trip
I'm at Biola on the bases of grace and grit. It’s the grace of God that brought me to an excellent institution and the grit required of me to do well in my studies.
Before I graduate in the fall of 2014, I have three amazing opportunities to take part in this year.

The first is to help make a feature length film in Jakarta, Indonesia from June 18th to July 17th.
The second is to make a short documentary in a smaller village in Indonesia after the feature film. We will be documenting their culture and teaching English.  
The third is the opportunity to study abroad in London during my fall semester at Roehampton University.
These different opportunities each have a unique outcome.

Indonesia will give me the opportunity play a part in telling a unique story through film. It will also expose myself and others to a different culture and language which will broaden my understanding of the way others think and relate to each other.
London will be an opportunity for me to interact with people that attend Roehampton University from around the world while traveling and studying the history of Europe and their style of filmmaking.
Both opportunities will expose me to different cultures, religions and worldviews that will allow me to better relate and work with those who don't share the same beliefs and cultural tendencies that I have. 
By helping to fund me, you will not only be helping to produce a movie, but you will also be helping me learn how to better listen to and tell stories of people around the world. 
What is needed
$8000 will fully fund my travel costs and room and board in Indonesia and London.
$2,000 of this will go toward the flight cost to Jakarta and Sulawesi, Indonesia. $300 will be going towards travel expenses in these areas. 
$5,000 will be going towards the travel cost to and from London along with the cost of living at the school from September to December. $1,000 will be going towards the cost of food and any other travel expenses.
What I have to offer to you? Myself. That is, showing you what I do during my time in these places through a short documentary, us getting to know each other on a more personal level through a skype conversation or letters, you receiving a canvas printing of any of my photography that I take during my time overseas, etc.
If I shouldn't raise the full $8,000, the funds will still help me go on these trips. If I raise enough for the flight costs to Indonesia and London and rooming in London, then I will at least be able to take part in both programs and figure out the food situation when I get there. 
The Impact
My hope is that these trips wouldn't just be about school or film-making. I desire to express the same love and hope that I've found in Jesus to whomever I meet on these trips. After all, this hope gave me a reason to pursue a college education in the first place.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you're unable to donate, there is still a way to help! You can...
1. Share my campaign with friends or family that might be able to help
2. Refer me to anyone you may know who could use high quality portraits done at a low cost between now and my trip dates. 
3. Refer me to anyone who could pay me to do miscellaneous chores  around their house between now and my trip dates. 
4. Pray for provision. 
Thank You for taking the time to learn a little bit more about myself and my campaign.

story:
Thank you for your interest in this campaign. You can still support our work to build a more Peace-Able world by visiting http://mediatorsbeyondborders.org/

Over the course of the last century human ingenuity has developed the means to completely eradicate all life on our beautiful planet. But we have also perfected the tools to reach an era of unparalleled human peace and understanding.

The 2013 MBB Istanbul Peace Conference is a working gathering of experienced and new peace builders sponsored by Mediators Beyond Borders International (MBB), a non-profit NGO. This event will bring together women peace builders from the Middle East and North Africa, as well as university students and professional conflict resolvers from around the globe. MBB now seeks to bring Istanbul to every corner of the world via live-stream.   

 This gathering will be the 6th Congress of MBB and will take place September 24-28 Nearly 300 peace builders from 40 countries will come together in Istanbul, Turkey to train each other, share experiences, and make plans to reduce violence and inter-ethnic conflict, counter the aftermath of genocide and civil war and to prepare for the coming human storms resulting from Climate Change.

The tools of non-violence, mediation, and community dialogue, rooted in many ancient cultures, have been raised to new heights in the last 100 years. MBB, founded in 2006, is building a network of practitioners who effectively use and advocate these tools from places as diverse as a village in Liberia, an urban conflict zone in Los Angeles, and the halls of the United Nations Conference on Climate Change.

William Ury, the famous co-author of Getting to Yes, stated: "I know and have respected the work of Mediators Beyond Borders for many years. The work they do to develop peacemakers and help build peaceable communities is needed now more than ever.  I am delighted and honored to support their work."

WHAT CAN WE ACHIEVE WITH THIS CONFERENCE?

Through the words of 5 world renowned speakers and 20 dynamic workshops this conference will prepare attendees, and thousands more watching online, to carry what they learn back to their respective countries creating a peace-driven multiplier effect that will shape not only their destiny but that of all humanity.    

With each and every new collaborator, this project continues to grow and flourish.  And, that’s where you come in! Will you help us spread the tools to create a more peace-able world?

FUNDS WILL GO TO …

Note: Contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law and international donations (e.g. £ €) are accepted and will be charged using the current conversion rate.

Our goal is to raise $10,000 by September 14, 2013 to supplement existing support. Your donation will make it possible for us to cover the following critical expenses: 

  • Cable Boxes for Live Streaming of Congress Workshops and Keynote Speakers:

We need $5000 for the cable boxes to provide on-line streaming of the Congress workshops and speakers to over 1000 peace activists around the world who can’t make it to Istanbul but are eager to learn from the masters who will be there. (You might be one!)  The film crew members have already generously volunteered their time and loaned their camera equipment. 

  • Transportation for Middle Eastern and African Women Peace Activists:

We need $5,000 to fund the attendance at least 8 more great women peace activists from the Middle East and Africa who have been accepted to come to our Training Institute in Istanbul but do not have personal funds to secure travel, accommodations, and food at the 2013 Conference without our help. 

 With one click of a button, you can become part of this campaign to change the world

If you would rather send a check, please make it payable to "Mediators Beyond Borders" with "2013 Congress" in the memo line and mail to: 1901 North Fort Myer Drive, Suite 405, Arlington, VA 22209, USA

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

TELL your friends, family, colleagues and neighbors about this campaign and share this page:

SHARE it through Facebook

SHARE through Twitter

If you’d like to contribute your expertise or connections to the project, please email us at: mbbcongress2013@gmail.com.

Thank you so much for being part of the growing number of forward-thinking corporations and organizations that support a more “Peace-“able" world. We’ll be updating this page regularly to inform on our progress, so please check back in and stay in touch. We’d love to hear from you!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Samantha. I am a single mom of 2 children. I am a blogger and a Business graduate from the Program at Lambton College. I have certificates in Indigenous Women in Community Leadership at St.Francis Xavier university and Aboriginal Management program at the Sauder School of Business. I need help with living expenses and/or tuition to attend the Royal Roads Bacholors of Commerce program in Entreprenuer Management. I would like to attend this year so I can get started in opening my business ASAP.

British Columbia is an expensive place to live, and I need any help that you can give, if its monetary or hiring me for a resume rewrite.

We all love perks, for helping me and my family, you get love and graditute, resume and coverletter rewrites, mentoring sessions or help writing a proposal for your business or non profit.

The Impact

The reason that I have studied business and am choosing this program is so I can open a teaching lodge upon graduation to assist women in starting small businesses. I believe women look at the impact business has from a social and community stand point and this will help us make more effective choices for our future generations and the planet. I think women in leadership make choices that are good for our children and grandchildren and that is why i want women to have a strong voice in board rooms, communities and within corperate structures. 

I need to have tution in order to accept the offer of admission, so time is of the essence. I have until September to accept the offer. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate at this time, I have a blog where you can read my writing and hear more about my views on business and indigenous culture. I am available for consulting and this will also help me pay some of my tuition. 

http://careeropportunist.wordpress.com/

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Support Mothers Become Financially Independent While Helping Their Children Learn 

 Fundraising goal:    $6000.00 USD

 

Cap Haitien is a city of approximately 1 million people on the north coast of Haiti.   Many Haitiens currently live on $ 1US per day.  Among these individuals, life is even more difficult for Haitian women—many of whom are uneducated, unemployed, and struggling as single parents of multiple children to support their families.  C-NEW-C is successfully helping these women and their children make a better life for themselves.  Our three-pronged program provides

  • nutrition  for malnourished infants and children
  • education for these youth and their mothers
  • micro-loans that empower  women to start small businesses and support their families. 

 

The reasons for Haiti’s widespread poverty, high unemployment, infrastructural deficiencies, and ongoing challenges are deeply embedded in its unique history, but have increased recently due to the massive earthquake in January, 2010, and the largest cholera epidemic in human history, that began less than one year later.  In the face of these obstacles, our nutrition, education and micro-finance programs are already making a huge difference. 

 

Here’s what we know:  Children who suffer from malnutrition at a young age also experience developmental delays and challenges to learning.  In response to this, we created a Pre-School in 2012 to serve the needs of the toddlers in our Nutrition Program.  The Pre-School curriculum is specially geared to the developmental needs of our children and delivered at a pace that is both appropriate and responsive to the severe challenges they have faced early on in their lives.   Once our kids complete the pre-school program, they are ready to enter the mainstream school system with success.

 

Here’s where you come in:  We need to expand our pre-school program to meet the needs of our youth.  We have 52 students in need of our pre-school program, but only a current capacity to enroll and serve 20.  Help us move to a new location that will expand our pre-school from 3 classrooms to 8 classrooms and allow us to hire 3 additional teachers.  Our new location will be situated closer to the homes of the families we serve in Cap Haitien.  And while these youngsters receive much-needed early childhood education, their mothers will be acquiring business and trade skills that will result in greater self-sufficiency for themselves and their families.   

 

 Our goal is open an expanded pre-school in September of 2013.  Help us expand our reach and empower more women and families to thrive and not just survive.

story:
MyMock is giving away 2 tickets to the 2014 NFL Draft!  Sign up for your chance to win!

MyMock lets you create your own mock drafts and compete against your friends and the nation to see who has the best draft knowledge! You will compete for cash prizes and bragging rights if you can beat some of the top professional analysts like ESPN’s Todd McShay. Show off your draft expertise and make sure you get a spot this year by checking us out on Indiegogo. We will have a limited number of spots available for this year's launch draft, so make sure you lock in your spot today on Indiegogo.

Screenshots from our mobile app.

                           

The money that we raise through indiegogo will be used to help fund development of mobile and web version of the game and give us bigger prize pools to offer for our leagues.

story:
What is Expedition Arunachal Pradesh?

“Expedition Arunachal Pradesh” is a photo documentary project by Jason K Powers covering one of the least known tribes in all of India.  Paired with the photo documentary, Jennifer Snyder will also be doing ethnographic research on this remote tribe.

There are many undocumented areas, many unseen faces, and so many untold stories in ‘the land of the dawn-lit mountains.’  One tribe has been chosen.  Jason intends to visit the Zakhring tribe who are positioned in one of the furthest north east regions of India in the valleys of the Himalayan Mountains of Arunachal Pradesh.

Arunachal Pradesh is bordered on three sides by Bhutan, China and Myanmar, with the rest of India to the South.  About ½ of Arunachal Pradesh is positioned in the Himalayan Mountains.

 

The Tribe: Zakhring

There is very little known about the Zakhring people.  A census done in 1981 revealed that there were only 14 members of their tribe remaining.  Living with the Zakhring people were another people group who identified themselves as the Meyor tribe, numbering around 240 people.  It is presumed that these two tribes merged at one time due to their low numbers.  If the population has continued to increase at a steady rate, the current population may be upwards of around 400, but if not, the population may have decreased to a startlingly low number, which could face the tribe with total extinction in the near future.  Interestingly, some sources suggest that neither of these names are the names in which they call themselves in their own language, which is the Charumba people.

The Zakhring peoples are believed to have migrated from Tibetat one time, and have resided in this area ever since.  Their religion is Buddhism which seems to be tinged with beliefs in a pre-Buddhist Bon religion.  It is not known whether they have their own literature or written language.

 

The Game Plan

Expedition Arunachal Pradesh has been broken down into two trips throughout the year.  The first trip was in early 2012 and served as more of a reconnaissance trip, including gathering information, visiting some of the places, talking to government officials, tour operators and the media.  Upon returning and sifting through lots of information and deciding on the specific tribe to document, Jason K Powers has commenced the task of putting together a small expedition to head back to Arunachal Pradesh in early 2013.

The decision to visit the Zakhring people was based on the fact that so little is known about this special tribe. Since they are also facing the possibility of total extinction, it is important to learn about such a unique people.  Jason felt that is was not enough to simply go in and ‘take photographs’ of these people, but to spend time with them and learn what he can about these people and share them with the world.

Through photography, Jason will be documenting, and telling the story of the Zakhring people.  Other plans are to be doing ethnographic research on this tribe with intent to release a book or small publications, telling the world about this tribe.

Jason intends to do various new and state of the art styles of documentary photography to be displayed in galleries, as well as creating a photo coffee table book about the tribe.  His photographs will also aid the research done by other anthropologist and Universities.

 

Where is India and the North East India?

Click here for a map – India | North East India

 

The Team:

Jennifer Snyder: 

Jennifer Snyder graduated in 2001 with honors from Colorado State University’s Anthropology Program. During her undergraduate education she also studied with the Rutgers Institute of Human Origins in Northern Kenya, and spent an entire year at University College London, dual enrolled in the Anthropology Program and the Institute of Archaeology.  She held internships in London at the Petrie Museum of Egyptology and the University College London Centre for Genetic Anthropology.

She went on to a graduate program at Washington University in St. Louis, where she earned a Masters in Anthropology and completed all required course work for the Doctorate program.  While at Washington University, she worked as a teaching assistant for undergraduate courses in both Cultural and Physical Anthropology.

After graduation, she took a position teaching multiple Anthropology courses at Trinidad State Junior College in Southern Colorado.  Over her lifetime, she has conducted Anthropological research and done field work in many countries, including the Southwestern USA, England, Portugal, Italy, Panama, Kenya and Morocco.

 

Jason K Powers: 

For the past 12 years, Jason K. Powers has been a freelance photographer based in the Lakewood, Colorado area. He has covered a wide range of photography from sports, photojournalism, weddings, modeling, headshots, documentary, editorial, environmental portraiture and general portraiture. Jason has worked with clients from families, to major magazines, PR firms, modeling agencies, newspapers and more.

While in Colorado he covers all of the Colorado High School State Championships for the Wallace Athletics & the Colorado High School Activities Association (CHSAA), as well as travels around Colorado and the country for various race event companies.

In 2006 he co-founded the non-profit, North East India Project (NEIP), where he served as President. NEIP worked with remote tribal villages in the jungles of North East India helping them to become more self-sustaining. Jason was among a small group of people who were the first foreigners to visit some of these places since the last 1800's. His first coffee table book, One Man's Road - A Journey Into North East India is scheduled to be out in 2013. 

Jason's love for travel, adventure, and the remote areas of the world has shifted his focus to documentary and ethnographic photography work these days. He has two primary projects going on right now.
Expedition Arunachal Pradesh is taking him to the remote jungles and Himalayan mountain tribes of Arunachal Pradesh, India, to study the last of the Zakhring Tribe. 
His latest local project, Denver's Hidden Homeless, takes him to the inner city of Denver, Colorado's hidden homeless population.

He has two primary projects going on right now.Expedition Arunachal Pradesh is taking him to the remote jungles and Himalayan mountain tribes of Arunachal Pradesh, India, to study the last of the Zakhring Tribe. His latest local project, Denver's Hidden Homeless, takes him to the inner city of Denver, Colorado's hidden homeless population.

story:
My name is Stephen Young and my wife is Karen. We work in a wholesale bakery called Global Specialty Products, Inc.We make some sweet stuff there.

In 2012 we decided to go to the Mathare Valley in Kenya to help feed families and kids. We got to work on the first water supply plant in this area.  We were so blessed by this trip we decided to help keep this work going.  The video you see is the one from our trip. It will give you a good idea of the needs there.

Our campaign is to raise $30,000 dollars to send another team to Kenya.  There is so much work to be done its hard to decide what to do first. The school has grown from a few kids to over 6,0000 young men and women. The school now  has a water well, a bottle plant and the first Hydroponics farm which is raising fish and growing vegetables

USE OF FUNDS

$10,000 of this money will be used to send 30 people to aid the families in Mathare Valley
$5,000 will be used to add equipment to the water treatment plant
$10,000 will be used and finish a new dorm room

$5,000 will be used to do dental work and buy medical supplies

WHAT WE WILL DO

Everyone will get pictures and video from the families in Kenya taken by the workers while there.

This is such a great work.  We can not tell you in words how blessed we were to go to the Mathare Valley.  This is one of the poorest places on earth and families are dumped there to die. The love the people have for you is amazing!  They truly look forward to our visits and their world is changing because of people like you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell a friend

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

Thank you,


Stephen and Karen

story:
Short Summary

Kids Who Love to Cook is a web series, with cooking videos featuring kids making lots of delicious dishes.

There are also videos that show where food comes from and how it's made — the kids go to Stowe, VT to learn how to make cheese and maple syrup, they check out an unban bee farm in Brooklyn and explore rooftop farms. 

We have food trips and contests, and we're always thinking of new ways to make food exciting for the beginner cook and young foodie.

The website is currently free of charge, and without any advertising. We want to keep it that way.

We want to encourage children to be curious about food, and build a passionate and engaged community who care about what we feed our body. Knowledge is power! We want kids to know about good food and eat well, and have a balanced attitude towards eating and life.

Have a look at what we do: http://www.kidswholovetocook.com

What We Need and What You Get

We want to produce Season 2 of Kids Who Love to Cook beginning Spring Break (we film when the kids are on school break).

Each video segment costs $1,500-2,000 to produce. A lot of us already work without pay but our production crew are struggling artists who can't afford to work gratis.

The creators of Kids Who Love to Cook have bootsrapped this project and are now producing other shows that are an off-shoot of KWLTC...new shows that feed the mind, and soul. We want to get our message out there, and we will continue to work as hard and as much as we can, with the little resources that we have. 

We are only asking for what we need right now, and every little bit can be used.

We have spent a lot of time thinking of ways to thank you...the perks...and we have come up with a lot of yummy ways to show you our gratitude. The truth is that we could never give back enough.

 

The Impact

Knowing how to cook is an invaluable life skill.

Cooking imparts a lot life lessons and is a terrific practice in planning, organizing, reading and math. Children naturally learn how to focus and be organized since cooking demands a certain amount of orderly, step-by-step way of doing things, an observance of basic rules and mastery of techniques. The payoff is something good to eat! Ahh...true self-esteem comes not from constant praise, but from being able to do things.

Good food, the kitchen, home, sense memory — more than just a cooking show, we at Kids Who Love to Cook believe that life's most meaningful moments happen during meals shared with family and friends: if a child knows how to cook, as one grows up, the home becomes an important place in one's life. Children from families who eat together do better in school, and later on in life.

Kids Who Love to Cook has gotten a lot of praise: we have been featured in the Chicago Tribune and we got USA Character approved within 2 weeks of our launch. (According to USA Character Network, "celebrating the people, places and things that are positively impacting American culture.")

http://www.kidswholovetocook.com/download/kidsw...

Other Ways You Can Help

Help does not just come in the form of money! Spread the word, tell your friends, connect.

<3 Kids Who Love to Cook

story:
Our life-long friend, Gia Godchaux, has recently suffered several health issues; blood clots, hysterectomy, and...breast cancer.  We are humbled by her courage, strength, and her amazing positive energy.

She has been unable to work since August 2012. We just learned that she is expected to be out for another six months. We (her friends and so many others whose lives Gia has touched) are trying to raise money to help her pay her house note, utilities, medicine, and necessities.  Your financial contribution will be appreciated more than you can imagine.

Thank you all so much.

WE WILL BEAT THIS.  Brest cancer will be defeated!

story:
Pushing Limits is a truly inspiring project!!!

Hi, I'm James Ketchell and I need your help to undertake the Ultimate Triathlon. Following my solo Atlantic row (2010) and summiting of Everest (2011), I've been fortunate that these experiences have enabled me to help young people broaden their horizons too.

Having established a programme of visits to schools, Scout groups and other youth organisations, the reaction I get has humbled and inspired me. And the greater the challenges I have met, the greater is my capability to inspire and motivate.

So, my goal is simply to use my experiences to inspire and motivate young people to set and achieve challenging goals – to push their own limits.

How can you help?

Step 1 - Buy a Perk (right hand side of this page)

Step 2 - Follow our blog on the website 

Step 3 – Like me on Facebook and tell your friends   

What is the Ultimate Triathlon?

The Ultimate Triathlon has never been attempted before. It consists of :-

  • Rowing the Atlantic
  • Climbing Everest
  • Cycling Round the World

In 2013, I will attempt the aim to complete the above within 365 days.

Row the Atlantic

I will row across the Atlantic Ocean, departing from La Gomera and ending after 3000 miles in Barbados. Setting off in January allows me to take advantage of the trade winds and currents that establish themselves at this time of year. I am to arrive 50-60 days later in time for the start of the Himalayan climbing season.

Climb Everest

Following the row I will head to Nepal to start the acclimatisation phase. Having already been fortunate enough to stand on top of Mount Everest, I am confident, but only too aware of how tough and unforgiving the environment is. Whilst in Nepal, I plan to document the story of the amazing Nepalese people and their culture as part of my education programme.

Cycle Round the World

On the 1st of July I will depart from London on a global cycle of just over 18,000 miles. I will have six months to cover the distance and make it back to London to ensure the Ultimate Triathlon can be completed within 12 months.

Why support Pushing Limits?

The ultimate aim of the project is to inspire young people to push their own limits and work towards goals that may appear difficult or impossible to achieve. Following my last Atlantic row and Everest climb, I have been visiting schools, Scout groups and other youth organisations, inspiring them to push their limits.

During every phase of the Ultimate Triathlon I will be linking up with schools around the world, sharing stories of my adventures and connecting them with other schools and youth organisations around the world to share their cultures and achievements.

Throughout the project I will also be raising awareness for the children’s charity The ELIFAR Foundation, an amazing organisation that supports disabled children, allowing them to achieve more. 

What motivates me?

In 2008 I was recovering from a serious motorcycle accident that left me with broken legs and a severely broken and dislocated ankle. The prognosis was that I was likely to suffer a permanent walking impairment and would certainly not be able to continue the active physical lifestyle I had enjoyed up to that point.

Undeterred, and after a lot of physiotherapy and training, I rowed the Atlantic single-handed in 2010, then on 16th May 2011 I reached the summit of Mount Everest.  

The Pushing Limits Team

I am lucky enough to be supported by a wonderful team of people, without whom this project just simply wouldn't be possible. They're all volunteers and give of their time freely because they're as passionate as me about helping the youth of today to broaden their horizons :-

Clive Arkell – Project Manager
Richard Cribb – Commercial Director
Richard Carman – Web Technologist
Mike Rawlins – Mentor and Coach
Tim Juby – Producer / Director
Tom MacDonald – Production and Development
Wendy Callaway – Finance Director

To learn more about my team please check out the team page of our website 

What We Need

The project is split into 3 sections. We are raising money through corporate sponsorship as well as individual donations. Support us now and 100% of the money we receive will go towards the Pushing Limits project.

Atlantic Row - $65,000
Everest Climb - $85,000
Global Cycle - $65,000

Total project cost - $215,000

 

Please help to make the Pushing Limits project a success...

story:
Let me start this by saying: This is NOT a year of me just having fun in another country. It's a lot bigger than that. It's about my education. This is a legitimate year of school for me, my junior year of high school. Obviously it is an amazing oppurtunity, but it'll be tough for me as well. Its much bigger than playing around in the streets of Finland. Please realize this, and thank you for reading on.

My Exchange to Finland

Hi, I'm Victoria, and I am a future exchange student from Illinois in the US, and I am going to Finland this August for about a year. This campaign is to raise the mandatory funds for my exchange. These costs include my insurance, my plane ticket, the mandatory language camp I have to take when I go to Finland, and several other things. With each dollar I raise here, it's a dollar less out of my parents' wallets. It's been my dream since I can remember to be an exchange student, and now that it's finally going to happen, I want to keep it as cheap as possible for my parents.

Isn't $7000 a lot?

Well, yeah it is, which is the problem I have. $7000 is so much money, and I can't help but cringe at the thought of my parents having to shell every single dollar out of their wallets. Anything over the $7000 I raise will be pocket money for me while I'm there, which would be pretty nice.

This exchange is something I've always wanted to do, and the fact that Rotary wants to send me to Finland is unbelievable. I'll get to study in a Finnish high school and stay with 1-3 host families throughout my year on exchange. The year in Finland will bring me unique experiences that I wouldn't necessarily find in America. I'll get a taste of a completely different culture and through the year I will learn new things about the world, as well as about myself.

The Big Impact

As an exchange student, I will be an ambassador for peace and understanding between people from different countries. I will go to different places and be able to break traditional stereotypes. When these stereotypes are broken, communications are open and people will realize that in the end we're all so similar. That is one of the coolest things about foreign exchange, in my opinion, and I'd love to be able to participate.

Don't forget to share!

I understand that not everyone has the money, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Please don't hesitate to share my page with your friends, family, co-workers, etc. Any amount of money helps me out and is greatly appreciated.

 

Thank you so much for your time and support, it really means the world to me.

story:
INTRO

"Artists share the calling, according to their disciplines and crafts, to cast the new images of mythology. That is, they provide the contemporary metaphors that allow us to realize the transcendent, infinite, and abundant nature of being as it is." - Joseph Campbell

Second-year NYU grad student/theatre artist here with a heartfelt plea for support as I endeavor to make my way to St. Louis for the conference of a lifetime! My name is Wilfredo Hernandez (bio and more info at www.whtheatre.com) and I'm a M.A. candidate at the NYU Gallatin School of Individualized Study where I am pursuing a concentration in Directing & Producing Theatre - mythic theatre to be specific. I'm entering into the last leg of my program and starting work on my artistic thesis, which entails both written and production components. Mythic Theatre is a term that I've created in the course of my studies and work to describe theatre that specifically examines myth (both narrative and symbol) through performance in an attempt to explore the meaning of the stories we as human beings hold so dear - both throughout history and in society today (i.e. political myths, stereotypes, creation/nature myths, heroic myths, love myths, etc.). I’m ultimately interested in learning how myths are embodied, performed, perpetuated and deconstructed. I believe theatre to be the best medium to accomplish this.

 

SUMMARY

“The myths told by the people should be studied and analyzed and their hidden truths revealed. In this task the theatre can be extraordinarily useful.”                         Augusto Boal

Aside from the study of antiquity, myth and theatre has not been addressed in a comprehensive way in academia or in the field at large. I hope to change this by examining timely issues of socio-political importance through a mythic lens. My thesis, entitled The Prometheia Project (TPP), will use the Prometheus mythos to examine issues of oppression, equality and power - specifically through the eyes of the LGBTQ community in the United States. I will work with a diverse collective of artists, scholars and activists to re-imagine the lost Prometheia trilogy of Aeschylus in an effort to create theatre that is epic in scope, generative and regenerative for artist, audience and community. After mounting the initial production this fall, I hope to replicate the frameworks and resources used for this project to work towards mounting various cycles of The Prometheia Project across the country and dedicated to issues of local, regional, national and international concern. In doing this, theatre can become a tool for community engagement, discourse and positive transformation. Attending this conference is the first step in achieving all of this and I invite you to be a part of what promises to be an exciting artistic journey. 

I was recently awarded a partial scholarship from the Gallatin Dean's Research & Travel Fund to attend the Mid-America Theatre Conference in St. Louis, MO, March 7-10. Celebrating its 34th year, the MATC conference has chosen MYTH as this year’s theme. It is a serendipitous occasion and truly a once in a lifetime opportunity to attend an event of this nature that is solely focused around my area of specialization. This partial scholarship will cover registration and food expenses, therefore I am turning to you for help in funding travel, transportation, lodging costs for this four day conference. These costs amount to approximately $800. Your help in funding this endeavor would not be simply to send a struggling graduate student to a conference - you would be contributing to the very development of the field of theatre and to the birth of a new theatrical form in America. This is a rare opportunity to tread new territory and contribute something to the legacy of one of this ancient art form. You would not be a funder or a patron – you would be a collaborator…a myth-maker. 

Full disclosure time – I will not be able to attend this conference without your support. My family and I, like so many who hail from central NJ and the East Coast, were hit very hard during Hurrican Sandy and finances have been extremely rocky as of late. In the interest of building open and honest communication, below is a breakdown of my expenses so you know exactly what is being funded:

TRAVEL

  • R/T Flight (NY-MO): $300.00 (with baggage & fees)
  • Ground Transportation:$50.00

HOTEL

  • Lodging: $450.00 (for 5 nights)

The conference is a four day event exploring the interesctions of myth and theatre with representatives from theatre companies, colleges and universities from across the country - this could very well be my first (and only) shot to explore my ideas in such a comprehensive and resource driven environment. To learn more about the conference, visit MATC

 

FUNDING STRUCTURE & PERKS

"...as societies develop, it is the artists who articulate the necessary myths that embody our experience of life and provide parameters for ethics and values. Every so often the inherited myths lose their value because they become too small and confined to contain the complexities of the ever-transforming and expanding societies. In that moment new myths are needed to encompass who we are becoming...we are in the space between mythologies."                                   Anne Bogart

This campaign is for flexible funding – which means that I will receive funds even if my goal of $800 is not reached. In the event that I do not reach my goal, the funds raised will still be applied directly to the cost of producing my thesis, which is the most helpful thing you could do aside from helping to fund this trip!

Again, I view your participation in this campaign as a collaboration –  collaborators are dependent on each other, as well as accountable to one another. It is in this spirit that I hope you will find the perks appropriate for this project. Please know that any amount donated to this campaign will receive a direct response from me and that I appreciate your generous consideration and spirit in considering this proposal. 

PERKS

  • $10 - FRIEND - A personal thank you email and listing of your name on my website!
  • $25 - GUIDE - A handwritten thank you note & picture of the mythic side of St. Louis + all perks listed above!
  • $50 - ORACLE - A phone call or online video chat where I will shower you in thanks and discuss my project and ideas about mythic theatre with you as well as discuss a myth of interest or importance to you and its symbolism + all perks listed above!
  • $100 - HERO - Your name will be listed in the acknowledgements section of my written thesis at NYU + a pdf copy of my thesis + all other perks listed above!
  • $250 - OLYMPIAN -  A “Patron” credit on The Prometheia Project + a professionally bound copy of my thesis + all other perks listed above!
  • $500 - TITAN - A “Chorêgos” credit on The Prometheia Project + two tickets to the premier in Fall 2013 + dinner with the cast and artistic staff of TPP + all other perks listed above! (NOTE: The chorêgos was a citizen of Ancient Athens who would contribute significant funds to the production of theatrical productions and festivals. It was a position of great honor in the ancient world and roughly means “to lead”)

 

THE IMPACT

"I thought it was a good idea, in times like ours, when nature speaks louder than men, to revive an ancient Myth that touches contemporary problems to the quick. I then had to make this Myth palpable and put it in words: For if nature speaks louder than men, it seemed to me that, with a few rare exceptions, the general tendency of the times was to forget to wake oneself up."                                                Antonin Artaud

As explained above, your contribution today will go towards building the future of a new field of study and practice in theatre! My idea of mythic theatre is for an art form that entertains and inspires, but also challenges and deconstructs. We have a very unique opportunity here to work together and explore some of our most pressing problems as a genuine community of peers...to creatively address these issues. The goal of my thesis and The Prometheia Project is to ultimately take on a national and international scope. You have the opportunity to be a part of this journey at the very beginning – I invite you, I honor you, and I thank you for your consideration as well as your spirit of generosity and aventure.

Take the journey with me…

Second-year NYU grad student/theatre artist here with a heartfelt plea for support as I endeavor to make my way to St. Louis for the conference of a lifetime! My name is Wilfredo Hernandez (bio and more info at www.whtheatre.com) and I'm a M.A. candidate at the NYU Gallatin School of Individualized Study where I am pursuing a concentration in Directing & Producing Theatre - mythic theatre to be specific. I'm entering into the last leg of my program and starting work on my artistic thesis, which entails both written and production components. Mythic Theatre is a term that I've created in the course of my studies and work to describe theatre that specifically examines myth (both narrative and symbol) through performance in an attempt to explore the meaning of the stories we as human beings hold so dear - both throughout history and in society today (i.e. political myths, stereotypes, creation/nature myths, heroic myths, love myths, etc.). I’m ultimately interested in learning how myths are embodied, performed, perpetuated and deconstructed. I believe theatre to be the best medium to accomplish this.
 
SUMMARY
“The myths told by the people should be studied and analyzed and their hidden truths revealed. In this task the theatre can be extraordinarily useful.”                         Augusto Boal
Aside from the study of antiquity, myth and theatre has not been addressed in a comprehensive way in academia or in the field at large. I hope to change this by examining timely issues of socio-political importance through a mythic lens. My thesis, entitled The Prometheia Project (TPP), will use the Prometheus mythos to examine issues of oppression, equality and power - specifically through the eyes of the LGBTQ community in the United States. I will work with a diverse collective of artists, scholars and activists to re-imagine the lost Prometheia trilogy of Aeschylus in an effort to create theatre that is epic in scope, generative and regenerative for artist, audience and community. After mounting the initial production this fall, I hope to replicate the frameworks and resources used for this project to work towards mounting various cycles of The Prometheia Project across the country and dedicated to issues of local, regional, national and international concern. In doing this, theatre can become a tool for community engagement, discourse and positive transformation. Attending this conference is the first step in achieving all of this and I invite you to be a part of what promises to be an exciting artistic journey. 
I was recently awarded a partial scholarship from the Gallatin Dean's Research & Travel Fund to attend the Mid-America Theatre Conference in St. Louis, MO, March 7-10. Celebrating its 34th year, the MATC conference has chosen MYTH as this year’s theme. It is a serendipitous occasion and truly a once in a lifetime opportunity to attend an event of this nature that is solely focused around my area of specialization. This partial scholarship will cover registration and food expenses, therefore I am turning to you for help in funding travel, transportation, lodging costs for this four day conference. These costs amount to approximately $800. Your help in funding this endeavor would not be simply to send a struggling graduate student to a conference - you would be contributing to the very development of the field of theatre and to the birth of a new theatrical form in America. This is a rare opportunity to tread new territory and contribute something to the legacy of one of this ancient art form. You would not be a funder or a patron – you would be a collaborator…a myth-maker. 
Full disclosure time – I will not be able to attend this conference without your support. My family and I, like so many who hail from central NJ and the East Coast, were hit very hard during Hurrican Sandy and finances have been extremely rocky as of late. In the interest of building open and honest communication, below is a breakdown of my expenses so you know exactly what is being funded:
TRAVEL

R/T Flight (NY-MO): $300.00 (with baggage & fees)

Ground Transportation:$50.00

HOTEL

Lodging: $450.00 (for 5 nights)


The conference is a four day event exploring the interesctions of myth and theatre with representatives from theatre companies, colleges and universities from across the country - this could very well be my first (and only) shot to explore my ideas in such a comprehensive and resource driven environment. To learn more about the conference, visit MATC
 
FUNDING STRUCTURE & PERKS
"...as societies develop, it is the artists who articulate the necessary myths that embody our experience of life and provide parameters for ethics and values. Every so often the inherited myths lose their value because they become too small and confined to contain the complexities of the ever-transforming and expanding societies. In that moment new myths are needed to encompass who we are becoming...we are in the space between mythologies."                                   Anne Bogart
This campaign is for flexible funding – which means that I will receive funds even if my goal of $800 is not reached. In the event that I do not reach my goal, the funds raised will still be applied directly to the cost of producing my thesis, which is the most helpful thing you could do aside from helping to fund this trip!
Again, I view your participation in this campaign as a collaboration –  collaborators are dependent on each other, as well as accountable to one another. It is in this spirit that I hope you will find the perks appropriate for this project. Please know that any amount donated to this campaign will receive a direct response from me and that I appreciate your generous consideration and spirit in considering this proposal. 
PERKS


$10 - FRIEND - A personal thank you email and listing of your name on my website!

$25 - GUIDE - A handwritten thank you note & picture of the mythic side of St. Louis + all perks listed above!

$50 - ORACLE - A phone call or online video chat where I will shower you in thanks and discuss my project and ideas about mythic theatre with you as well as discuss a myth of interest or importance to you and its symbolism + all perks listed above!

$100 - HERO - Your name will be listed in the acknowledgements section of my written thesis at NYU + a pdf copy of my thesis + all other perks listed above!

$250 - OLYMPIAN -  A “Patron” credit on The Prometheia Project + a professionally bound copy of my thesis + all other perks listed above!

$500 - TITAN - A “Chorêgos” credit on The Prometheia Project + two tickets to the premier in Fall 2013 + dinner with the cast and artistic staff of TPP + all other perks listed above! (NOTE: The chorêgos was a citizen of Ancient Athens who would contribute significant funds to the production of theatrical productions and festivals. It was a position of great honor in the ancient world and roughly means “to lead”)


 
THE IMPACT
"I thought it was a good idea, in times like ours, when nature speaks louder than men, to revive an ancient Myth that touches contemporary problems to the quick. I then had to make this Myth palpable and put it in words: For if nature speaks louder than men, it seemed to me that, with a few rare exceptions, the general tendency of the times was to forget to wake oneself up."                                                Antonin Artaud
As explained above, your contribution today will go towards building the future of a new field of study and practice in theatre! My idea of mythic theatre is for an art form that entertains and inspires, but also challenges and deconstructs. We have a very unique opportunity here to work together and explore some of our most pressing problems as a genuine community of peers...to creatively address these issues. The goal of my thesis and The Prometheia Project is to ultimately take on a national and international scope. You have the opportunity to be a part of this journey at the very beginning – I invite you, I honor you, and I thank you for your consideration as well as your spirit of generosity and aventure.
Take the journey with me…

story:
My name is Cathi Book. I am a retired Periodontal Hygienist turned Mission Worker. My mission: To help provide orphaned children in Kenya a secondary education.

HIV/AIDS has taken its toll on many families in Kenya, leaving in its wake, more orphans per capital than any other country in the world. There are extremely limited resources for the proper care and development of these precious children.

I have been to Kenya twice, once in March of 2011 and the second time in February of 2013. Kenya itself is making slow progress but orphaned children are still very much at risk.  Orphaned children turn to the streets, hoping to make a living selling whatever they can find. Unfortunately, more often than not, they are used by gangs or for prostitution. Forced into illicit drug and alcohol activities or shipped off as slave labor.  

Some start their schooling but due to financial/family/housing issues miss more school than they are able to attend. Unable to complete their education, they turn to the streets as a way to earn a living. 

I met Tobias in March of 2011, after he had been a part of Each One Touch One Orphanage (EOTOO) for about a year. He had tried to survive as a street child but was failing and abused. He was a bright, respectful boy, who was genuinely appreciative of his new life and family at EOTOO.

Tobias and I spoke again in February of 2013. He is still the same kind and respectful person I first met but has become more confident. He is an above average student with strong potential. Small for his age but filled with hope and promise, he understands what life is like for children of his background, without an education, and longs to do something more with his life...He has a dream!

Primary education in Kenya is from Standard (Grade) 1-8. The cost of uniforms and standardized government testing is costly for parents and orphanages. Secondary education is not paid for by the Kenyan Government. It consists of four more years of academic training before taking government tests for college placement. All Kenyan children must have financial backing to attend secondary school. In the case of orphans there is usually no financial backing. Most orphanages cannot afford the cost.

The Kenyan Department of Children requires that all children living in orphanages must become totally independent by age 17-18. Tobias' time at EOTOO is quickly coming to an end. At 16-1/2 years of age, he is now the oldest child living at EOTOO. He has two options: 1) Be sponsored to attend secondary school and work hard to achieve the test scores needed to attend University/College or 2) Find a way to earn a living on his own. Even trade Schools are non-existent or financially unaffordable to orphans and non-orphans alike. 

The cost of secondary education in Kenya is $2000 US per year for four years. A total cost of $8000 US.  All secondary schools in Kenya are boarding schools. Children must leave their families and travel to a school designated by the government, as determined by that particular child’s standardized test scores.  Tobias has just finished taking the tests and scored well, 350 points out of 500 points. This means he is eligible for a secondary boarding school.

The $2000 US/year cost of the boarding school includes all room and board, tuition, uniforms and shoes including underwear and socks, books and educational materials, travel from EOTOO to the boarding school and back, all government required tests, incidentals such as toiletries, paper and pencils…Only the essentials.  

Tobias must be able to pay his first installment to the boarding school by January 1, 2014. The head mistress of EOTOO, Alice K., will make the arrangements for his travel and attendance at boarding school. Any funding collected by this campaign will be placed in a fund for Tobias through PurposeQuest, a long standing non-profit, established by Dr. John Stanko, Administrative Pastor at Allegheny Center Christian and Missionary Alliance Church located on the North Side of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Dr. Stanko has been raising funds for EOTOO and other orphanages and programs in Kenya for more than 17 years. He visits these orphanages and programs two to three times a year personally. This campaign will be administered through Dr. Stanko's non-profit. Any funding of this project will be designated and earmarked for this Campaign.

For more information regarding Purpose Quest or the other programs established by Dr. Stanko, please go to http://purposequest.com/contributions.

Funding for Tobias will be held in escrow and used as needed. Receipts for all spending will be required from EOTOO and the boarding school, even for incidentals. Tobias will be held accountable for his progress in school. He will also be required to send letters monthly concerning his experiences at school. The receipts, test scores and letters will be available on the PurposeQuest website.

Our initial goal is to raise enough funding for Tobias' first two years of secondary school, which is $3,800. If and when that goal is reached, the funding over the goal would be spent to support him through all four years of secondary school. Ultimately we would like to be able to support many deserving orphans in this way.

Tobias has a dream to encourage and mentor his orphaned brothers and sisters. Giving hope and a "leg up" to others is quite a dream for a young boy. I can personally vouch for his integrity. If anyone can reach his dream, Tobias can. 

Someone once said "Feed a man a fish and he eats...teach a man to fish and he can feed himself"! Self-esteem is an important key for a brighter future. A hand-out is no help. A "leg -up" is the beginning of healthy independence. 

So what can you, as one person, do to make a positive difference in such a vast and seemingly desperate situation? Have you ever heard the old adage, "How do you eat an elephant?"..... The answer: "one bite at a time."  

Will you stand with Tobias and take that first bite? Offer that "leg-up"? Even if you cannot give support financially, would you partner with him in prayer? Be an encouragement to him? Pass this campaign on to others you know who may be able to help? We are connected to Facebook and Twitter. Indiegogo provides the tools necessary to spread the word.  Any support given will be extremely appreciated! God Bless You!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Tsvia Horesh. I am an Israeli music therapist with 23 years of experience, working with children, youth and adults with varied  emotional and physical disabilities.

This campaign aims to send two Israeli music therapists to Yangon, Myanmar, for 4 weeks, to work with staff in special education schools. The Israeli volunteers  will support the local staff in establishing sustainable “music as therapy” programs in their schools. I will join them for the first week of the project, to oversee and pass on my experience to make sure that the project will run smoothly in my absence and continue to support them in their work via skype after that.

Myanmar is a country in S.E. Asia which has recently been going through significant political, social and economical changes. Most of the helping professions commonly used in the treatment of special needs children – music therapy being one of them  – are not taught in Myanmar universities. By helping fund this project you can contribute to the empowerment of local educational staff, and through them, to the enhancement of the  emotional and social well being of special needs children.  

What is Music Therapy

Music Therapy is an established health profession in which music is used within a therapeutic relationship to address physical, emotional, cognitive, and social needs of individuals.  It is implemented by a  credentialed professional who has completed an approved music therapy program.

Clearly we are not going to train people to be music therapists in 4 weeks. But our experience has shown that intensive, hands-on training, can be beneficial in enabling local staff to use music in a therapeutic way for the kids they work with.

This project is being done in partnership with the Music as Therapy International Charity http://www.musicastherapy.org/ .

 

What We Need

The parents the Montessori Home for Children in Yangon, one of the schools we will be working in, are very keen for their children to continue to enjoy the benefits of  regular music sessions.  They have managed to secure all our accommodation and food for the whole 4 weeks. This really does prove how committed they are to receiving more input from us.

In addition, we need to raise 6500$ to cover air tickets, local transportation, visas  and an emergency fund.  Any extra money will be used to buy more musical instruments for the schools and to cover ongoing support for the local partners.

The Impact

Last year I spent 2 1/2  weeks in Myanmar, teaching 25 teachers from 9 different  special education schools in Yangon – the basics of therapeutic music techniques . The participants were very enthusiastic about starting music as therapy programs in their schools, but also apprehensive about how they will do this on their own, after finishing the course. I came back 5 months later for a 3 day followup.

This course was supported by:

* the Israeli embassy in Yangon,

 *Triangle Génération Humanitaire - an international humanitarian NGO http://trianglegh.org/,

and *ECDC – Eden Center for disabled children Yangon http://www.edencentre.org/

I wanted to make sure that I was delivering the training to the best of my ability so I sought consultancy from the UK charity Music as Therapy International . This charity has been delivering introductory music as therapy skill sharing projects overseas for over 15 years so they have plenty of experience! They  were so impressed by what I & the local partners had managed to achieve that they have offered their support again this year for phase 2 of the project

 This project is  responding to a need that the schools expressed. As you can see in the attached video, since last year’s course they have been using music therapeutically with the children they work with. But they need more professional input and support – and so asked for this continuing  program.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cant contribute money, you can help spread the word! Please share this campaign with all your friends and contacts.

Your help, no matter how small, will have a direct impact on one of the many children attending the Eden centre and other local schools. These disadvantaged children most probably won’t have the opportunity to learn to express themselves and develop their social skills without the help of music therapy. The teachers are desperate to learn new ways of connecting with and developing relationships with these children.  

Join us and be a part of bringing music therapy to Myanmar!

story:
Welcome to our fundraising page!

Be The Hope began as a dream and desire to do more. My name is Heather Hinze and I am a 40(ish!) single mom of a 16 year old daughter and a licensed foster parent. Thanks to a pair of shoes, a book, water, a burlap bag and a hatred of cubicles I am taking a leap of faith to realize my dream of changing the lives of children in Haiti. To learn more about how it all started, please visit my blog: www.bethehopehaiti.wordpress.com. 

Our Mission

Be The Hope is a non profit organization with a mission to provide a backpack full of school supplies to children in Haiti, which will help alleviate the financial burden on their families. We believe education is a human right, not a privilege.

The Impact

We are starting with 150 children in Cite Soleil. The children are from Agape Orphanage, La Main Tendre Orphanage, Frem Orphanage, Cite Soleil Youth Center and Mix Emmanuel Primary School. Cite Soleil is in Port au Prince, Haiti. It is the poorest and most dangerous area in the Western Hemisphere and also one of the largest slums in the Northern Hemisphere. An estimated 150,000 of Cite Soleil’s residents are orphaned or abandoned children. Seventy percent of these children are school age; however they do not attend school. In Haiti, 55% of the population lives below the poverty line of $1.25 per day. Due to the cost of school fees, school supplies, and uniforms many families can't afford to send their children to school.

We believe if all Haitian children had access to an education, their potential to both end the cycle of poverty and contribute to the recovery of Haiti would increase. According to UNICEF, education contributes to greater civic participation and helps to combat youth violence, sexual harassment and human trafficking. It also results in a range of health benefits including lower infant mortality, reduced domestic violence and improved child nutrition. For many Haitian children, a school lunch is the only meal that they can count on receiving all day. Education can foster social empowerment, enabling an entire generation to become economically independent and positive contributors to society. Education is an important part of the successful rebuilding of Haiti.

The Backpack Project

Our goal is to raise enough funds to purchase 150 backpacks, which we will deliver in May 2013. Each backpack will include:

  • 1 - backpack
  • 1 - hand pencil sharpener
  • 1 - 24 count crayons
  • 2 - 100 page composition notebooks
  • 1 - 12 count #2 pencils
  • 1 - pencil case
  • 1 - eraser
  • 1 - 10 pack ball point pens
  • 1 - 12" ruler

We have partnered with a company that will pre-assemble the backpacks to our specifications. A complete backpack can be purchased for only $25.00! If you're a parent of a school age child, think about what you spend every year on school supplies. If you're like me, the backpack alone is more than $25.00. 

If we do not reach our fundraising goal, we will purchase as many backpacks as we can with the funds raised. 

If we surpass our goal (as we hope we do!), there are many more things that we would like accomplish! The schools are also in need of chalk, chalkboard erasers, and arts and crafts supplies. There's already another school of 106 children that is in desperate need of help and we would LOVE to help them. No penny will go to waste!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute financially, but you can still help us reach our goal!

  • Please tell ALL of your friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues about our cause and this campaign.
  • Share this campaign with Indiegogo share tools. Share with your email lists and social media contacts.
  • Become a fan of our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/bethehopehaiti
  • Follow our blog on www.bethehopehaiti.wordpress.com
  • Visit our website www.bethehopehaiti.org
  • Check out our Amazon Wish List for additional needed items that we would like to bring to Haiti  http://amzn.com/w/FU237H4GPEN3 
  • Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/bethehopehaiti
  • Set up your own fundraising event to benefit Be The Hope's mission!

It is the poorest and most dangerous area in the Western Hemisphere and also one of the largest slums in the Northern Hemisphere. An estimated 150,000 of Cite Soleil’s residents are orphaned or abandoned children. Seventy percent of these children are school age; however they do not attend school. In Haiti, 55% of the population lives below the poverty line of $1.25 per day. Due to the cost of school fees, school supplies, and uniforms many families can't afford to send their children to school.
We believe if all Haitian children had access to an education, their potential to both end the cycle of poverty and contribute to the recovery of Haiti would increase. According to UNICEF, education contributes to greater civic participation and helps to combat youth violence, sexual harassment and human trafficking. It also results in a range of health benefits including lower infant mortality, reduced domestic violence and improved child nutrition. For many Haitian children, a school lunch is the only meal that they can count on receiving all day. Education can foster social empowerment, enabling an entire generation to become economically independent and positive contributors to society. Education is an important part of the successful rebuilding of Haiti.
The Backpack Project
Our goal is to raise enough funds to purchase 150 backpacks, which we will deliver in May 2013. Each backpack will include:

1 - backpack
1 - hand pencil sharpener
1 - 24 count crayons
2 - 100 page composition notebooks
1 - 12 count #2 pencils
1 - pencil case
1 - eraser
1 - 10 pack ball point pens
1 - 12" ruler
We have partnered with a company that will pre-assemble the backpacks to our specifications. A complete backpack can be purchased for only $25.00! If you're a parent of a school age child, think about what you spend every year on school supplies. If you're like me, the backpack alone is more than $25.00. 
If we do not reach our fundraising goal, we will purchase as many backpacks as we can with the funds raised. 
If we surpass our goal (as we hope we do!), there are many more things that we would like accomplish! The schools are also in need of chalk, chalkboard erasers, and arts and crafts supplies. There's already another school of 106 children that is in desperate need of help and we would LOVE to help them. No penny will go to waste!
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that some people just can't contribute financially, but you can still help us reach our goal!

Please tell ALL of your friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues about our cause and this campaign.
Share this campaign with Indiegogo share tools. Share with your email lists and social media contacts.
Become a fan of our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/bethehopehaiti

Follow our blog on www.bethehopehaiti.wordpress.com

Visit our website www.bethehopehaiti.org

Check out our Amazon Wish List for additional needed items that we would like to bring to Haiti  http://amzn.com/w/FU237H4GPEN3 
Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/bethehopehaiti

Set up your own fundraising event to benefit Be The Hope's mission!

story:
The Cherokee Historical Association (CHA) is a non-profit organization founded in 1948 and is located in the heart of the Qualla Boundary, commonly known as the Cherokee Indian reservation in Western North Carolina.  Our mission is to “perpetuate and preserve the history and culture of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians.”  Since 1949, CHA has provided employment opportunities to Cherokee’s who are interested in maintaining our cultural heritage and sharing its richness with the rest of the world.

 

For those of you that may be unfamiliar with the story of the Cherokee people, during the 19th century, the U.S. government forcibly removed the majority of the Cherokee nation from the southeast United States.  The Cherokee’s marched west to Oklahoma on what is known as the Trail of Tears.  Many of the Cherokee perished during the forced removal.  A tiny few were allowed to remain in the traditional homeland of the Cherokee where they were faced with racism and poverty.  CHA portrays that story and strives to keep the traditions, language, and crafts of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians alive.

 

CHA operates two attractions for the education and entertainment of the traveling public here in Cherokee.  “Unto These Hills” is one of the nation’s foremost outdoor dramas. Debuting in 1950, Unto These Hills has been performed for over six million visitors throughout 62 years of operation.  The Oconaluftee Indian Village is a living, working Cherokee village of the 18th century.  Here, centuries old techniques for survival pass from generation to generation and are preserved in this living history site.

 

Gifts to the Cherokee Historical Association will be used to enhance our programming and educational projects for both the public and our Cherokee employees.  Your donations will help us continue to pass along our unique culture for future generations.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Colleen. Michelle and I left for Japan on the same day in 2004 to join the JET Programme to teach English in high schools in Japan.  Michelle has Lupus and while teaching there she became too old to stay on her parents' insurance.  Since returning would mean a gap in health insurance coverage unless she could land a job while still out of the country, she was essentially trapped in Japan, moving from terrible job to terrible job after the economy collapsed in 2008, needing to hold on to her connection to health care.  In order to return she would need to find a job with insurance.  Job searching from out of the country was impossible, but if she went back to search for jobs she would be uninsured for the duration since Lupus is a pre-existing condition that makes it impossible even to pay for it.

Michelle is a dedicated teacher, and wants to continue her education in information sciences to work as a medical librarian, teaching and helping medical students and doctors find the health information they need. Her background as a teacher, writer, researcher, and her history with the medical system give her all the tools she needs.   She will excel at this, but now has worry and debt hanging over her.  Let's help! 

This year (2013) she got into graduate school with some funding and most importantly - insurance, so her Japanese doctors sent her home with some secret meds to tide her over for the three months until school started and her assistantship would start to cover health insurance.  Unfortunately Michelle's heart decided not to cooperate and she spent five days in the ICU, uninsured.  She had a pericardial effusion due to complications of her Lupus. This means the sack around her heart filled with fluid and could barely beat. Miraculously, massive doses of antibiotics narrowly avoided surgery.  She is fit again and ready for school, but now the bills are due.

As she says, "I also had a brush in with a horrid woman from collections while I was in the ICU. Who talks to a heart patient with no health insurance about money while she's strung out on morphine? She came in to see if I qualified for financial assistance from the hospital but then told me I didn't qualify after asking me a handful of questions. I got annoyed and asked her how an unemployed woman with no health insurance and who would be starting grad school in a month not qualify. She explained that they had already done a credit check on me and since I never had anything repossessed and I paid my bills on time they felt I could make another payment...The hospital alone was around $32,000. Because I was uninsured they dropped it to $11,000. They would have dropped it to $8,000 if I could have paid within ten days of leaving the hospital, but I didn't have that kind of money just lying around. 
I am also getting additional bills trickling in every day for individual departments, tests and doctors within the hospital. Yay."

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

Michelle owes $11,000 and with her family they have set up a payment plan so that she can still go to graduate school.  We have set a goal of $500 to give Michelle a cushion to help since she will also have all the expenses of moving to her new city, setting up an apartment, and getting her books and supplies.  $500 is a mere fraction of the $11,000 she suddenly owes so if we meet the goal, please continue to give and every bit will go to easing the burden of medical debt.

 

Your reward:  

If you donate $5 or more you will get an email update from Michelle about how she is doing at her new graduate school.

If you donate $50 or more, Michelle will read any piece of your writing (up to 20 pages, 12 pt font, double spaced) and provide editing and critical feedback.  

For $100 or more Michelle will translate the document of your choice from Japanese to English, up to 3 pages, or translate up to 5 minutes of audio dialogue from Japanese to English.  

 

The Impact

Michelle is a dedicated teacher who has found a field that suits her well.  With a small cushion to help her through she can focus on graduate school and get a job to make a big difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and use Indegogo's share tools to get the word out.

story:
See our website for updates:

http://cusd.cornell.edu/ssa/

Our Story

In the past academic semester, Cornell students have catalogued existing and potential sustainable practices in South Africa and have created a comprehensive atlas of their research.  This 200-page atlas will inform the design of a 6,000 square foot Early Childhood Development center (known locally as a crèche) and is currently in three of Cornell's libraries and throughout the design studio. Cornell architecture students will complete the design within the next few weeks and the crèche will be constructed by volunteer students during Summer 2011 in Cosmo City, South Africa. 


The Impact

Currently, children in Cosmo City attend school in a 6ft x 6ft room with 79 other students.  This will be the first official crèche in Cosmo City.  With the introduction of Schoolhouse South Africa's crèche, children up to age 7 will be able to attend a school that affords them space to learn and play.  

This project also includes a teacher training center that will allow for other schools to have their teachers trained by Education Africa.  In this way, the benefit of our school is not limited to only the students attending the school.


What We Need & What You Get

The schoolhouse will cost ultimately around $150,000.  We are looking to reach a minimum of $50,000 here on indiegogo.com within the next two months.  This money covers only materials and permits.  The labor to build the crèche is all volunteer (30 eager students and 10 local African laborers), and the travel cost will all be covered by the volunteers as well.  We are very fortunate to also have the support of alumni of the CUSD program, the school, and family and friends.

The book from our extensive research (for use in the design phase, as well as to encourage other people and organizations in similar projects by providing a solid starting point) can be seen here.

CUSD Schoolhouse: South Africa Research Compilation Book


Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for contacts to help us make Schoolhouse South Africa a reality.  Any material donors in South Africa, professional companies in building related fields, are always welcome to contact us and discuss those types of contributions.

story:
Education materials and warm clothing for children in Peru

Connecting Borders Foundation has been helping children in Peru for 3 1/2 years, as well as the co-founders personally helping for 4 years before that.  This year, in August, we will be returning to Peru for a 2 week trip, taking some volunteers.

We have raised the funds to purchase 2 computer systems (2 PC/Servers, with 4 monitor stations each) to take to an all girls dormatory in Ollantaytambo, Peru.  We will also be visiting an orphanage in Oropesa that we provide monthly support to.

Our next goal is to provide every kid at both organizations with backpacks, stuffed with school supplies, and warm clothing/blankets, at a minimum.  We will be arriving just as they are returning to school from the Winter Break.

What We Need

We need to raise at least $500 to purchase backpacks and warm clothes for all the kids at both organizations.  We will be purchasing all supplies locally, in Cusco, to help the local economy as well.

Here's how your contributions will help:

If we raise...

$500 - Brand new backpacks and blankets/warm clothing.

$600 - Paper, pencils, erasers, pens, crayons, etc. to fill the backpacks.

$750 - New socks and underwear for all kids to start the rest of the school year, with the backpacks and school supplies.

$1000 - $125 stipend at each location to help replenish school supplies for the rest of the school year.

$2500 + - We would purchase more multi-station computers for these and other organizations, as part of our CBF Education Network.

 

What you get:

#1 - Satisfaction knowing you are helping children that wouldn't normally have a chance at a decent education, get one.

$25 donation- You will receive 1 authentic handmade cloth bracelet from a market in the Sacred Valley. Patterns will be randomly chosen.

$50 donation - You will receive 1 authentic handmade cloth bracelet and 1 set of gloves. Patterns will be randomly chosen.

$100 donation- You will receive 1 cloth bracelet, gloves, and hat.  Patterns will be randomly chosen.

The Impact

To date, we have been helping an orphanage, Azul Wasi, in Oropesa, Peru, outside of the legendary Incan capital city of Cusco.  We provide them a monthly stipend to pay for electricity, internet, educational costs, and the cooks salary.

This year, we are expanding our reach, and helping the Sacred Vallery Project, in Ollantaytambo, Peru.  They provide a dormatory environment for girls aged 12-15 that are from the surrounding villages, to continue their normal schooling, that would normally be taken out of school permanantly due to the amount of time it takes to reach school each day from their remote villages.  We will be providing them with a special computer system with math videos in Spanish, as a supplimental education option.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please let others know about our trip to help the kids!  You can contact us through our website, www.connectingborders.org,  if you have any questions.
