Every contribution will help make a difference!Follow MeNow that I have a twitter account, I'll be able to update you guys on the campaign, my trip, and other related events! Every funder will receive a shout out on twitter so don't forget to follow @Nanaeguitar!

story:
Short Summary

We are the HUNCH team at Lakewood High School in Lakewood, CO. We are a part of the student division of the Research and Engineering Department of Johnson Space Center in Houston, TX.  We are creating a system called a "hydrofuge" that will allow plants to grow in a microgravity environment. This system will go up to the International Space Station (ISS).However, being students, we have to fund the project ourselves.

Our system uses a centrifuge to keep the plant alive. A centrifuge is used to spin components or mix nutrients. In our case, we are using it to spin the plant to get water off the roots. We are implementing this system because in microgravity, water will not drip off the roots like it does on Earth. In microgravity, water sticks to plants roots instead of dripping off. The centrifuge spins at a high enough rate to sling the water off of the roots, preventing root rot. The water collects at the bottom of a tear-drop shaped chamber, and is pumped out of the chamber to an IV bag. The chamber is tear-drop shaped because water is naturally attracted to certain angles (80°). Nutrient-laced water is pumped back and forth between the IV bag and the chamber every six hours to keep the plant watered and fed. LED lights, together with the centrifuge, help the plant grow vertically because plants naturally grow towards the strongest source of nearby light.

The Impact

This is an once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for our team. We will be sending five students to Ellington Field; three of them will be flying and two will be on the ground, to ensure the success of the project.

  • This system is a proof-of-concept to test the design and hopefully expand upon this system in the future and allow astronauts to grow actual food in space.
  • Our design will have been tested four times in microgravity before launch to the ISS.  Our final test will be aboard NASA’s Zero-Gravity aircraft, stationed at Ellington Field in Houston, Texas. 
  • The students flying in microgravity are seniors, this means that this is their last chance to do something like this.
  • You will be making a student's dream come true.

This is where you come in!

  • To do this, we need $750 per team member, putting us at a grand total of $3,750.
  • We are high school students so our perks are limited to what we can do for you. 
  • At $10, we will give you a handwritten thank you letter and a HUNCH Sticker.
  • At $15, we will record our whole team and express our gratitude on a video and email it to you!
  • At $50, we will put your businesses logo/name on a poster that will  go up in our school and be seen by 2000+ people.
  • At $100, we will put your businesses logo/name on a banner that will go with us to the Ellington Field.
  • If we don't reach our goal the funding will still help us go to Houston.
  • If we go over our goal, the money will go to helping us send the hydrofuge to the ISS.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, it doesn't mean that you can't help!

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Share this to your friends, family, and people that you think can help!

Anything helps us!

story:
You can help a aspiring Doctor go to a UK university and become an astrobiologist!


Hello! I'm Iain Nolen-Weathington, American Whovian and astrobiologist-to-be. Because of these two interests and my inherent love of foreign culture, I want to go to the UK for university. Unfortunately, university of any sort is a "wee bit" expensive. My mother's office had a fire over a year ago, which more than halved our family income and she is only now getting back to full pay. Because of this, we went through our savings so I am going to need help. This is where you come in. Please help this Doctor meet other aliens - send me to uni!

Why the UK?

I want to go to the UK because I would get to experience a new culture and environment in an exceptional educational system. I have already been accepted to University of Glasgow, University of Edinburgh, University of Exeter, Aberystwyth University and University of Hull, all excellent universities that would give me a great start in my career. Although these universities do not have astrobiology programs they do have excellent marine biology and evolutionary biology programs, both of which easily serve as proxies for astrobiology for an undergraduate program, especially when considering the weird extremophiles that inhabit the least hospitable areas of our world. The UK is home to several astrobiology organizations including the UK Centre for Astrobiology and the Astrobiology Society of Britain. 

Also as a fan, the UK would be a wonderful place to explore. Seeing the very places that were featured (and invaded) in Doctor Who episodes would most certainly be an exciting experience. Even as an (American) alien, I am certain I would blend in at least as well as I do here with my bow tie and fez, because they are cool.

How can we obtain our goal?

The goal for this campaign is international tuition and room and board for either University of Glasgow, alma mater of Steven Moffat and home of Peter Capaldi, or University of Edinburgh, home of the UK Centre for Astrobiology. If the goal is not met, it may still be enough for one of the other unis, which still gets me to the UK. Even $5-10 helps get closer to the goal. 

What can we do for you?

As can be seen on the side, there are many perks for certain levels of donation. 

  • Polandball Portrait- A portrait of a country of your choice in the style of Polandball. This style can be seen in the picture above.
  • Button- A button displaying the slogan "I sent the Doctor to Uni". Perfect for placing on a backpack or shirt
  • Polandball Comic- A Polandball comic involving countries of your choice. You can even make the plot if you so desire.
  • Necklace- A necklace portraying the campaign slogan and a cartoon version of an extremophile of your choice.  
  • T-shirt- A T-shirt portraying the campaign slogan and a cartoon version of an extremophile of your choice.

Remember, even if you can't contribute, you can still help by getting the word out!

With your help we can reach our goal and send this Doctor to University

story:
I am a college student who is supporting herself through school on a waitress salary. I barely make enough money to pay rent and bills, but I get by. I work 3-6 days a week & go to school 2. I have betewen 1 & 3 days completely off both a month. Some days I go to school all day then work until 2am & then right back to work the next morning. I have been working very hard to complete an Education Bachelor's Degree that will certify me to teach ESOL (English as a second language), Spanish and Special Ed. I am in the top percentile of my classes. I am absolutely beyond thrilled to be able to teach, especially when I will be able to teach ESOL (which I currently volunteer teacher's assisting ESL at the IRC refugee center and nothing in the world inspires me more). My main concentration is in Spanish and therefore requires a study abroad to a Latin American country. My family is very supportive in every way, but we were hit very hard by the economic recession. The program is not very expensive as study abroads go, but I just am not able to save that much after rent, bills and tuition from restaurant tips. The $5000 goal I have set for my fundraising campaign is juuust enough to pay for the tuition abroad and the progam fees (which include 2 out of 3 meals a day, airfare, and to stay with a host family). The $500- $1000 I need to bring for spending money/cab fare to campus, etc I am scrimping & saving for myself.

I need your help! Feel free to donate as little or as much as you want, but every dollar helps! My campaign only lasts 60 days per the website rules, so please dont wait until later.

I WILL be coming back with prizes for those who donate

This will include:

I will set up a travel blog facebook page before I go and will launch it once I have scraped together all the money to go. I will post daily updates of classes, outings, interactions with my host family, and of course pictures. 

Alpaca gloves and scarves

Hand woven Incan prayer tapestries

Other hand made artisan market trinkets

Framed photos of Maccu Piccu and other historic locations around Peru

Once I graduate, I will be certified to teach Spanish, ESOL & Special Ed in K-12 Georgia public schools. I will offer several hours of either spanish lessons to English speaking donators or ESOL lessons for second language speakers if you donate at the $1000 level. 


Please help my cause, I have worked very hard on my degree & it is crucial that I study in a Spanish speaking country!

Here is a link to the KSU Education Abroad Office's website on the program:

http://kennesaw.studioabroad.com/index.cfm?Fuse...

Thank you!

<3 Dana

story:
Dear family and friends,

Last year in March I traveled to southwestern Uganda to volunteer with a new health care non-profit organization that Bill, my boyfriend, co-founded and currently heads. During my three weeks in the dusty town of Kabale which is just north of the Rwandan border, I worked with a team of 14 other volunteers – doctors, dentists and dental hygienists – to help run medical and dental clinics. I specifically helped to run the mobile pharmacy with Bill’s mom, working with local Ugandan nurses to fill prescriptions from 21 huge hockey bags that we had stuffed with donated medications from basic pain killers to reading glasses.

During one of the especially busy clinics which was held at a local school called Muyumbu Primary School nestled in the lush hills of a valley about an hour’s drive from Kabale, one of the local community leaders named Robert (also known in the community as “Kukuru”) pulled me out and suggested that I go speak to one of the classes.

I walked in and saw 70 school children jammed into a tiny classroom, all bright-eyed and giddy. Robert then announced to me that they had prepared a song for me. After his go-ahead, the whole class broke out into song, clapping their hands and singing together with huge smiles on their faces. Afterwards, Robert asked if I wanted to say a little something to them. I saw nothing but happiness and hope on their faces, and I took a couple minutes to tell them about the importance of studying and doing well in school, so that they’d have the ability and the skillset to go off in the world and be whatever they wanted to be. At the same time, my heart sunk looking around realizing that the school itself was so strapped for educational resources and that most of these children lived in utter poverty.

It was a sobering moment for me, thinking about how much my brother Albert and I have been given growing up, and how we were afforded every opportunity to make something for ourselves because of the sacrifices of our parents. We were, and still are, so very lucky. And so grateful.

And so that brings me to the core of this message to you all (sorry it took this long!). Albert will be going on the second annual trip with TO the WORLD (the non-profit organization) back to Kabale, Uganda along with Bill and 26 other doctors, nurses, dentists, dental hygienists, pharmacists, and other volunteers in mid-February. Before he goes back, and I know there isn’t too much time, he and I wanted to raise $1000 to buy at least one laptop for the Muyumbu Primary School, a school that serves 713 students, has 21 teachers, and does not have any computers. NONE.

With one laptop (and I know it’s not much), the school administration will be able to use this new property to store school information, access internet in the rare case they are able to access wi-fi, and also help print documents when they schoolmaster is able to make it into town.

Albert and I would be ever grateful if you could help us raise this money – and it would mean so much more to the 713 students and 21 teachers that it will help.

Anything that you can donate would be appreciated, and thank you in advance for helping us pay it forward.

Love,

KC & Albert

story:
My name is Dylan Sansone and I am a junior at Clark University in Worcester, MA. I have always had a passion for helping others and have decided to pursue a college degree that would allow me to further this passion. I truly believe in the notion  that we need to be the change we wish to see in the world. Therefore I took it upon myself to  pursue every opportunity I could to try to further my knowledge in order to better be able to help others. I was fortunate enough to be able to attend the Brown University Leadership Institute where I studied leadership and conflict resolution. I am also an alumni of the Congressional Youth Leadership Council where I had the opportunity to further develop my leadership skills and knowledge of development.

After being accepted to Clark University I began to study entrepreneurship. It is through my studies that I was introduced to the field of social entrepreneurship (SE). This exciting field seeks to remake the relationship between the public and private sector. In a nut-shell the idea behind SE is that we can make non-profit organizations more effective by making them more sustainable. This sustainability can be derived from applying market principles in the form of a product or service. The profits from that service or product can then be re-invested helping to sustain the non-profit cause in the long-term which increases its effectiveness. This emerging field will have major implications for the non-profit sector and has the potential to change the way the world addresses development on a global scale.

 This funding will allow me to travel to Nairobi, Kenya with Clark University Dr. David Jordan to conduct research and to participate in the first ever Seven Hills Global Outreach International Conference. This conference will bring together social entrepreneurs  from around the world to exchange ideas, learn from one another and grow. As a student this is a once in a life-time opportunity and I am very excited about it. Being able to go on this trip is important to me because I will be able to pursue my academic passions that much further and will be able to see what I have been studying for the past several years first-hand. Not only will this provide me with first-hand field-experience, but I will also be able to meet with people and organizations that have a massive impact on our world today. Many of the organizations that will be present are helping to re-shape the way the international community addresses development and the non-profit sector. Having the opportunity to be a part of this process will help me to find my place in this emerging field and will ultimately help me to be the change I want to see in the world.

Being able to go on this trip is important to me because I will be able to pursue my academic passions that much further and will be able to see what I have been studying for the past several years first-hand. Not only will this provide me with first-hand field-experience, but I will also be able to meet with people and organizations that have a massive impact on our world today. Many of the organizations that will be present are helping to re-shape the way the international community addresses development and the non-profit sector. Having the opportunity to be a part of this process will help me to find my place in this emerging field and will ultimately help me to be the change I want to see in the world.

story:
Christmas Kindness


The Cambodian Children's Shelter

I recently volunteered at a children's shelter in Cambodia, called Les Restaurant des Enfants. Each day, this wonderful organisation in Phnom Penh provides over 100 children with meals, a shower and a safe place to stay. At the shelter, the children can receive basic hygiene and health care, have their hair cut and enjoy the unwavering support from the shelter's loving staff. By providing the children with life's basics, the shelter takes some of the financial strain  off the families and the children are then able to enjoy their young lives a little bit more.

All the children at the shelter are happy and polite, despite their own daily struggles. Some of the children are homeless and spend most of their time scouring the streets for cans, tying to sell odds and ends or begging. Many children have lost their parents to AIDS and other diseases. Others live in tiny rented rooms with their families, but they too have to work each day to support themselves and their loved ones.This Christmas you can make a difference by donating to Les Restaurant des Enfants.

 

A little goes a long way

Any donation, great or small, will make a huge difference to the shelter and the orphaned, homeless and poor children that they support. Your donation can help the shelter in many ways.

We all understand the importance of food and you can help the shelter  provide nutritious meals to its hungry youngsters. 

  • Beef for one day: $60 [8kg]
  • All food needed for one day: $160 
  • Noodles for one month: $ 210 [30 boxes]

Even poor and homeless children are entitled to have a little fun. Do you want to bring smiles to the children's faces?

  • Excursion to the Royal Palace or Swimming Pool: $35 [small group, includes return tuk-tuk and entry prices]
  • Toys, books and games: $50 [general]

Some of the homeless children live a long way from the shleter. Would you like to make sure the homeless children get to the shelter each day?

  • One month tuk-tuk: $75 

Remember, you can also give a general donation to help the shelter continue providing for the children each day.

Sponsor a Child

Sponsoring a child is the greatest gift because it allows them to focus on their education and escape poverty. Your sponsorship pays for their education and schooling materials, as well as basic health and hygiene care. It also means they no longer have to work and can enjoy their childhood.

One year sponsorship: $360

Remember, if you make a donation to sponsor a child, you are making a commitment to sponsor them for their whole childhood. We will contact you with details of your sponsorship once you make your donation.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to donate, you can still help!

Post this link to your facebook page, send your friends an email or let people you know about this cause.

 

Thank you so much.

 

Love Elly xx

story:
Short Summary

Post-Session is a milestone of the ARISE High School experience. Students take three-week intensive courses related to arts, creativity, or physical education. As a teacher, it allows me to teach the passions I have beyond the discipline I teach everyday. For students, it allows them to explore beyond the traditional academic disciplines, to get out of the classroom, build community across grade levels, and cultivate new passions. Students who haven't always done well in Math or English find new confidence and competence when they can explore other strengths like drawing, painting, dancing, biking, or mountaineering. Post-Session culminates in an exhibition night in which each course presents what they did and learned to the community at large. You are welcome to join us to see the impact of your contributions.

Our course offerings this year are as follows:

ACTIVE RESISTANCE

Journey with us as we will find our Zen, strengthen our core, and learn healing strategies that speak truth to power.  Active Resistance will provide you with the tools to endure struggle on all fronts of your life, be it physical, mental, emotional and spiritual.  Participants will increase their physical strength through traditional Muay Thai Kick Boxing, boxing and yoga, find their center by practicing daily meditation and participating in a Native American sweat lodge ceremony, go on an overnight amongst California's serene coastline and explore what Hip Hop, health, and higher education have to do with resistance. 


I WANT TO RIDE MY BICYCLE!

We will bike the Bay Trail, the Headlands of Marin, Tennessee Valley, China Camp, and all over the East Bay. Students will learn bicycle safety, maintenance, and repair in addition to biking themselves into great shape. The course will culminate in a three-day overnight stay in the Marin Headlands. Trips for Kids will take us out mountain biking on trails in the surrounding area. Bikes!

REEL TO REAL: THE ROLE OF WOMEN IN FILM

We are going to watch films, examine them and then make them. We are going to spend the morning watching and analyzing and then spend the afternoon filming and making film--specifically focusing on female archetypes, gender roles, and feminist critiques in film.

HOMIES EMPOWERMENT

Students from the Homies Empowerment "Adelante" Leadership Program will embark on a 3-week journey throughout California learning their history from the change makers themselves. They will spend time in the home of UFW Leaders Cesar and Helen Chavez. Student will travel to Los Angeles to learn from leaders such as Father Gregory Boyle about Homeboy Industries. Students will also spend three days at a sweatlodge ceremony learning from Indigenous elders about healing ceremonies in our community.

URBAN ARTS WITH 1AM GALLERY

In this 3-week artistic journey, students will study, explore, and create a diverse selection of urban arts that include: graffiti, murals, stencils, photography, and mixed media.  Students will create beautiful art pieces with the help of various guest urban artists from all over the Bay Area. 

ROOTS RISING

 Roots Rising is a multi-media Hip Hop Theatre course.  In this course we get real with truth. We live as Word Warriors to confront our stories and take them to the stage and movie screen.  Using Spoken Word Poetry, Dance, Music production, and video production, we will produce a Hip Hop theatre piece that we will perform during Exhibition night. 

OH, THE PLACES WE'LL GO (2 sections)

In Oh, the Places We’ll Go! we will explore attractions throughout the Bay Area, such as Coit Tower, the Golden Gate Bridge, the Exploratorium, and other hidden nature spots right in Oakland. All these exploring skills will be tested on a 3-day backpacking trip to one of the Bay Area’s most scenic spots.

 

 
HIPPIE ARTS
 
We will be making: T-shirts, lotion, jewelry, sculptures, herbal tea, glass bedazzling and MORE! Also learn about hippy culture and history, interpretive dance, hula hooping, tour a local welding and glass-blowing shop, non-violent communication, the Mayan calendar, and drum circles. 
 
ETHNIC DANCE AND DRUMMING
 
In this post session, students will explore a variety of ethnic dance and drum taught by local professional dancers and dance educators.  A preliminary list of dance styles includes: Taiko Drum, West African Dance, Puerto Rican Bomba (dance, drum, and song), Folklorico, Hip Hop, Brazilian,...and more!  Students will choreograph and perform their own creative dance piece that is rooted in these learnings!
 
EXPLORING THE OUTDOORS
 
Students will condition their minds, bodies and spirits to live, work and play in the natural world. They will learn how to camp safely and responsibly in the woods, how to avoid hazards from plants, animals and the physical environment, how to move and navigate in difficult terrain, how to perform first aid, and how to be present, mindful and connected with nature. The class will culminate in a week-long camping and backpacking trip in Sea Ranch, CA.

What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately, statewide budget cuts have gutted our funding for Post-Session and left us to raise the funds ourselves. Each course will receive $500, which means we need to raise $5500 to support the 11 course offerings. Each course spends the money a little differently, but it is generally used for transportation, supplies, and guest teachers. For instance, the bicycle course uses the money for bicycle parts, snacks, and lodging for the overnight trip. The film course uses the money for camcorders, props and transportation.

As for perks, you will certainly receive kharmic bonus points, a sense of glory and accomplishment, and...most importantly...a thank you card from our students. If you give more than $100, we will list you on our program at the exhibition night for all the post-sessions.

The Impact

Over the past 6 years Post-Session has been offered, we've seen countless students discover their passions. Many students decide what they want to study after high school. And almost all students return to the classroom energized, more confident, and more ready to learn. Students also build relationships across the grade levels, with students who they don't have in their daily classes. This builds the familial, connected feeling of Arise High School.

Your contribution will help 250 students participate in post-session. It will enable students to receive the requisite Art and PE credit they need to graduate, while also exposing them to new topics, experiences, and modes of learning.


The importance of intersession according to students:

"In Sports Around the Bay we got to go to parks all over the East Bay and play everything from basketball to ultimate frisbee. It allowed me to get out of my head and all the stress of my daily life. When we went camping, we could share with each other and really become friends with students we didn't know that well," Jennie.

"Post-session gives you three weeks where you don't have to stress about academics, but can focus on new experiences and making new friends. I loved spending three days in the Marin Headlands with the other students. We got to bond over some challenging bike rides and at night at the hostel. You just can't bond like this in the classroom," Eric.

"I think post-session is great because I can connect with my teachers outside of the classroom. It helps us humanize one another," Maria.
 
"At first, I thought Mr. Damon was crazy for making us drink that green sludge (energy shakes). Then I tried one and it wasn't as disgusting as it looked at it made me feel great. After the class, it was funny to see kids walking down the hallway with those green shakes," Marco.
 
"After bicycling, we were able to go the Bikery and earn free bikes. I started biking to school everyday. I think about half the class did too," -Chris.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, we get that. We're broke teachers, after all. You can still help, however, even if you don't have any funds. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word. Help us connect with folks who might have money. Also, if you have any of the following to contribute it would be of great help:

Bicycles and Bike parts: if you or someone you know has a bike that's just collecting dust, you can donate it. If you happen to have spare parts or tools lying around, we'll take those too.


Art supplies. Of all sorts.

Digital Recording equipment: if you have camcorders, digital cameras, microphones, digital audio recorders, etc. We'd love them.

story:
Short Summary

Real-World Training Solutions(R-WTS) has discovered that a majority of the police departments and sheriff’s offices in the United States do not have access to leading edge training technology, specifically use-of-force simulators.  City and county budgets are stretched thin and the funds needed to purchase this training technology, typically $30,000 to $150,000, are just not available.  R-WTS is helping solve this problem by purchasing these expensive systems and then renting them out to law enforcement agencies on a daily or weekly basis at a much lower rate that will fit into almost any agency’s budget.

  

 Why is training on a simulator important? 

Simulators are great training tools because officers can Experience it before they live it!  Officers have the opportunity to work out techniques and tactics while life and limb are not on the line. Training on real-world situations and environments saves lives! Law enforcement officers that use leading edge training equipment work safer and reduce risk to themselves and the public. Using a use-of-force simulator helps officers build a mental rolodex… hopefully they will never find themselves in some of the situations you can put them in using a simulator (like active shooter in a school for example) but if they ever encounter this situation, or something similar, the time in the simulator will help them develop a quick and effective response. 

The Marion Police Department testimonial on the R-WTS web site is a great example that you should check out.

 

What We Need 

We need your help to purchase more of these life saving training tools.  By purchasing more systems we can help more agencies and their officers.  Currently we are constrained by a lack of funds to purchase additional systems becasue we price the rentals for affordabillity not profitability.

 

What are we going to do with the money?

The funds we are seeking will be used to purchase more use-of-force simulators (laptop computer, high definition projector, portable screen 12 feet x 7 feet) and training weapons.  Each system needs the following specially modified training weapon: (2) Batons, (2) Pepper Spray Canisters, (2)Tasers, (4) handguns , (2) shotgun and (2) rifles.

If we exceed our goal, the additional funds will be applied toward the purchase of another system if we have enough. If not, funds will be applied toward maintenance and the purchase of additional weapons for the systems we currently have.

 

How the system works:

A use-of-force simulator is a computer based system that uses a high definition projector to project a video scenario on a 7’ x 12’ screen. Up to 4 officers, using specially modified weapons, interact with the screen depending on how the scenario unfolds. The video scenarios have branching options meaning that the outcome can be different depending on the actions of the officers or the specific training need. For example, if an officer uses good verbal commands the on screen suspect can be made to comply with the officer’s request. The scenario can be rerun and the next time the verbal commands are ineffective and the suspect chooses to pull out a gun or attempts to assault the officer which causes the officer to react accordingly.

story:
Short Summary: Bridging Digital Divides

“Maybe the next Albert Einstein, or the next Steve Jobs, is living somewhere in a remote village in Africa.” - Stanford Professor, and pioneer of online education, Daphne Koller at the 2012 TED conference.

Unfortunately, awesome online content can't help these future Einsteins without a bit of creative intervention. That's where we, you, and our partners here in East Africa come in. Lack of knowledge about online learning tools, and the inability to afford to download data (especially video) are two of the largest hurdles, both of which Tunapanda is working to solve.

We are two brothers in our mid-late 20s who believe that harnessing technology to spread education is key to creating the most awesome possible future. We've been incredibly lucky to live on 4 continents so far, and had access to great educations – and think everyone else should have such access as well. So we've started telling people in Kenya about the new free online learning tools and courses, downloading the ones we can, and distributing them for free. Kenya has state-funded education through 8th grade, so we focus on teenagers who can't afford to go to high school – there are hundreds of thousands here each year, and untold millions around the world. 25% of Kenyans in 8th grade don't continue to high school, and 40% of those finishing high school do not proceed to further education or training. There is also a severe shortage of teachers, particularly in the technology sector.

We aren't limiting ourselves to East Africa, just starting here – we hope eventually our system, or something like it, can be deployed anywhere in the world, whether deep in the Congo or in any city in our home country.

 

Problems & Solutions

Internet is very expensive relative to income in Kenya and much of the world, even if you have an internet-capable computer or phone. And while most people know about Facebook, hardly anyone knows that Khan Academy has the entire high school curriculum, or that they can learn computer programming from top professors for free on Udacity, Coursera, or edX. In rural Kenya it costs less to buy a DVD full of video than to pay for bandwidth to download it, and DVD players are more common than home computers – we're leveraging that fact to get around high internet costs.

We also spread and teach free and open source software, and teach kids about upcoming technologies like 3D printing, so they can both start dreaming about changing the world, and actually start doing it. We work directly with students, but focus mainly on training teachers so they can spread it without needing us. Using free and open source software is more practical than philosophical – people can't afford half of their family's annual income for an operating system license, and while pirating is widespread we'd rather avoid risking going to jail or wasting time, energy, and money in legal battles. Free and open source software is just as good, if not better, in most cases anyway.

Our tag line is “Bridging Digital Divides” - because we want to connect everyone with the valuable learning resources on the internet, and also help them come online and share their unique perspectives and local knowledge with the rest of us. They have a lot to teach the us “digital natives” too.

 

What We Need & What You Get

FYI: Tunapanda is a Swahili word meaning “we are planting,” “we are growing,” or “we are climbing.” It's not a fish-bear.

In our Phase 1, which lasted the past 4 months, we partnered with 3 different organizations and became intimately familiar with the problems here. We've been using online learning resources to continue our own educations for at least 2.5 years, and have taken courses on at least 4 platforms, so we used that experience to spread the right knowledge and courses.

We need at least $25,000 for Phase 2, which we expect to last 4-6 months. At least half of all money raised will go to upgrades at our partners' schools, starting with TIIT – a technology school in rural Elburgon that uses 12-year-old computers and has a half-finished dorm that could allow them to accommodate 15-20 more students. You can see TIIT and hear from one of their co-founders in our video above.

The rest will go to setting up Tunapanda's central hub in Nairobi, where we'll bring local teachers and students for advanced training, work with people on the internet (like you, perhaps?) who want to help us out in our forums, get set up as a 501(c)(3) based in the US, pay for local legal & visa fees, and begin spreading regionally. We've partnered with 3 groups, detailed on our website, and have 2-3 more in mind to begin working with soon. For example, the Duke-sponsored WISER school in a far-flung corner of Kenya teaches girls STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Math) skills but would like to put their computers to better use.

By the time Phase 3 rolls around, we hope to have more reliable forms of funding, like committed donors and grants, as well as an easily-replicable hard drive with an easily-understood path to mastery in various subjects. Then we hope to do some really cool stuff, most of which will be copied from successful project all over the world, or which people who work with us either online or on the ground have come up with.

Closing Remarks

If you visit our website you can see more information about our management and directors, as well as a snapshot of what's in our “education on a hard drive.”

You can help at no cost by sharing this campaign however you see fit, or going to an online learning platform and taking some courses – which helps the content creators we spread improve their products.

You can also go visit our forums and start sharing ideas, or meet people in your area who would like to join you in spreading all these great tools and courses to people who don't know about them or can't afford access.
story_txt:
Short Summary: Bridging Digital Divides
“Maybe the next Albert Einstein, or the next Steve Jobs, is living somewhere in a remote village in Africa.” - Stanford Professor, and pioneer of online education, Daphne Koller at the 2012 TED conference.
Unfortunately, awesome online content can't help these future Einsteins without a bit of creative intervention. That's where we, you, and our partners here in East Africa come in. Lack of knowledge about online learning tools, and the inability to afford to download data (especially video) are two of the largest hurdles, both of which Tunapanda is working to solve.
We are two brothers in our mid-late 20s who believe that harnessing technology to spread education is key to creating the most awesome possible future. We've been incredibly lucky to live on 4 continents so far, and had access to great educations – and think everyone else should have such access as well. So we've started telling people in Kenya about the new free online learning tools and courses, downloading the ones we can, and distributing them for free. Kenya has state-funded education through 8th grade, so we focus on teenagers who can't afford to go to high school – there are hundreds of thousands here each year, and untold millions around the world. 25% of Kenyans in 8th grade don't continue to high school, and 40% of those finishing high school do not proceed to further education or training. There is also a severe shortage of teachers, particularly in the technology sector.
We aren't limiting ourselves to East Africa, just starting here – we hope eventually our system, or something like it, can be deployed anywhere in the world, whether deep in the Congo or in any city in our home country.
 
Problems & Solutions
Internet is very expensive relative to income in Kenya and much of the world, even if you have an internet-capable computer or phone. And while most people know about Facebook, hardly anyone knows that Khan Academy has the entire high school curriculum, or that they can learn computer programming from top professors for free on Udacity, Coursera, or edX. In rural Kenya it costs less to buy a DVD full of video than to pay for bandwidth to download it, and DVD players are more common than home computers – we're leveraging that fact to get around high internet costs.
We also spread and teach free and open source software, and teach kids about upcoming technologies like 3D printing, so they can both start dreaming about changing the world, and actually start doing it. We work directly with students, but focus mainly on training teachers so they can spread it without needing us. Using free and open source software is more practical than philosophical – people can't afford half of their family's annual income for an operating system license, and while pirating is widespread we'd rather avoid risking going to jail or wasting time, energy, and money in legal battles. Free and open source software is just as good, if not better, in most cases anyway.
Our tag line is “Bridging Digital Divides” - because we want to connect everyone with the valuable learning resources on the internet, and also help them come online and share their unique perspectives and local knowledge with the rest of us. They have a lot to teach the us “digital natives” too.
 
What We Need & What You Get
FYI: Tunapanda is a Swahili word meaning “we are planting,” “we are growing,” or “we are climbing.” It's not a fish-bear.
In our Phase 1, which lasted the past 4 months, we partnered with 3 different organizations and became intimately familiar with the problems here. We've been using online learning resources to continue our own educations for at least 2.5 years, and have taken courses on at least 4 platforms, so we used that experience to spread the right knowledge and courses.
We need at least $25,000 for Phase 2, which we expect to last 4-6 months. At least half of all money raised will go to upgrades at our partners' schools, starting with TIIT – a technology school in rural Elburgon that uses 12-year-old computers and has a half-finished dorm that could allow them to accommodate 15-20 more students. You can see TIIT and hear from one of their co-founders in our video above.
The rest will go to setting up Tunapanda's central hub in Nairobi, where we'll bring local teachers and students for advanced training, work with people on the internet (like you, perhaps?) who want to help us out in our forums, get set up as a 501(c)(3) based in the US, pay for local legal & visa fees, and begin spreading regionally. We've partnered with 3 groups, detailed on our website, and have 2-3 more in mind to begin working with soon. For example, the Duke-sponsored WISER school in a far-flung corner of Kenya teaches girls STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Math) skills but would like to put their computers to better use.
By the time Phase 3 rolls around, we hope to have more reliable forms of funding, like committed donors and grants, as well as an easily-replicable hard drive with an easily-understood path to mastery in various subjects. Then we hope to do some really cool stuff, most of which will be copied from successful project all over the world, or which people who work with us either online or on the ground have come up with.
Closing Remarks
If you visit our website you can see more information about our management and directors, as well as a snapshot of what's in our “education on a hard drive.”
You can help at no cost by sharing this campaign however you see fit, or going to an online learning platform and taking some courses – which helps the content creators we spread improve their products.
You can also go visit our forums and start sharing ideas, or meet people in your area who would like to join you in spreading all these great tools and courses to people who don't know about them or can't afford access.

story:
Do you know anyone who just never seems to say the right thing?

Or someone who constantly makes bad decisions? Who has grand dreams, but never seems to take the steps to achieve them?

It’s likely someone came to mind, but the fact is: we all have failings. It’s a part of human nature that, though we can detect these apparent flaws in others, we rarely recognize these things in ourselves--and even more rarely know how to change them.

For the last four years, our company, Neuro Innovations, has been chasing an elusive goal: creating a simple, easy-to-use and highly accessible tool that will help everyday people build on their strengths, tackle their weaknesses, and reach their full potential.

The answer lies in neuroscience. Such tools exist, but are held in a corporate sphere, only accessible to a few, wealthy individuals. A typical assessment, in the current industry, can cost around $500 to $1000 per person. This technology was, until now, regrettably out of reach for the rest of us.

This campaign exists to create, maintain, and distribute our solution to this problem: NI360, a digital assessment using industry-standard technology, made affordable for the common individual or business. The 360 can give everyone the chance to better understand:



By contributing to this project you will be helping everyday people gain powerful personal insights that would ordinarily only be available to people of wealth, status and power.


You contribute to our campaign and you will receive a full 360 personal evaluation for the absurdly low price of $25.

This 360 will measure how the people around you (using input from them) perceive you across 48 different metrics, allowing you to truly understand your impact on them.

When we launch, you will receive an email invitation to take the 360 evaluation online. It should take you less than 10 minutes to complete. Then you put in the email addresses of a few friends, family, colleagues and presto - when they answer their questions about you, you will receive a link to your report.

It's as simple and brilliant as that!

And if you are a personal Life Coach, you can buy a pack for your clients - get a really solid understanding of who they REALLY are from the people around them! 

We are raising money to pay for the 360 Programming engine.

The question "How can we give people true insights about their social impact in an affordable way?" brought us to the idea of creating a robust online engine. We have found programmers and have created literally thousands of pieces of dynamic text which, once scored via the 360's advanced system, will reveal the user's true personality (as perceived by both yourself and others). The 360 will also be able to tell you where your shortcomings and opportunities lie.

But first the engine needs to be built.

The programmers have begun the task and are on target for a January delivery. We are planning on using the month of January to iron out all the bugs and run some tests before sending you your own personal invitation as our sponsor, to complete your own 360 evaluation.

Regrettably, most people never get access to this type of assessment.

Neuroscientific insights into your life and business are invaluable, and in today's technological day and age, it's a shame that people should be denied access to it.

In the past several years, one of our focuses has been culture change in organizations: stemming from the idea that 80% of resources go to the top 20% of the company. Considering that additional resources may be needed at a higher level makes sense to a degree, until you realize that this upper level only produces 20% of the change--wasting 80% of the budget!

Measuring the Social Intelligence of everyone in an organization, family, or in any situation leads to a deeper, more wholesome, and useful ways to understand and interact.

With the NI360, organizations will be able to get this type of information on their entire staff!

In smaller contexts, consumers like you and me can deeply understand how we are perceived and what changes can make in our lives to be even more effective in the world. 

How cool is that?

If a financial contribution is out of the question right now, please consider helping us to spread the word about the 360 Assessment. You can use the sharing tools beneath the video on this page to let people know about this opportunity, or you can visit our website at www.ni360.ca to learn more about our product and goals.

Everyone needs a little help from time to time understanding the impact of their actions. Consider sharing this campaign with people who could make the most of it, including:

  • Life Coaches
  • Corporate Coaches
  • Therapists
  • Social Workers
  • HR workers
  • Entrepreneurs

And anyone else who might be curious about the impact that they have on those around them.

Thank you for taking the time to go over our campaign, and we hope to be in contact with a 360 Assessment shortly!

story:
Make It Rain!

Watch the video above and experience the thrill of virtually causing rain, moving water and earth, all by playing in the sand! Watch as Dr. Shane Rogers, Clarkson University professor & project supervisor, creates Denning's Point and makes it rain!

Help us support SENSOR PLACE by December 20th!

With Your Help

You too can get your hands on (literally) this awe-inspiring exhibit by contributing to our campaign bringing it to the public at Beacon Institute's Sensor Place at 199 Main Street in Beacon, NY.

With your support, this 3D Interactive Watershed  can become part of a unique Main Street destination for young learners and visitors of all ages to explore and discovery the Hudson River and estuaries around the world.

The Impact

Sparking a passion for water & inspiring an interest in science

Beacon Institute for Rivers and Estuaries, Clarkson University, serves our community with engaging river and nature education programming. Our storefront location on Main Street allows us to reach the public directly, already with water-focused Gallery exhibits and public nature programs, and now too with hands-on science learning accessible to everyone.

The Details

Your contribution to this project will enable us to permanently install a new 3D Interactive Watershed in our storefront science discovery space. Funds raised will go to the transport, installation, and optimization of the 3D Interactive Watershed for permanent use in SENSOR PLACE.

The 3D Watershed is being developed as a Clarkson University student-led project overseen by associate professor of environmental engineering Dr. Shane Rogers. This project uses cutting-edge technologies to create a new kind of virtual exploration tool available in only a small number of public venues worldwide. It   requires significant time and resources to complete and install it at Beacon Institute.

Perks for Supporters

We so appreciate your contribution to our Sensor Place project, we want to show our gratitude with Donor Perks! See sidebar for details.

Pre-Launch Reception for Donors on 12/4!

Be among the first to experience the 3D Watershed Exhibit and SENSOR PLACE. We invite donors and their family members to our Pre-Launch Reception, an evening celebration to show our appreciation with exclusive access to our new discovery space before it launches. Event will take place Friday, December 4th from 5-7pm and will include light refreshments!

Funds we receive in excess of our goal will be applied to other SENSOR PLACE projects. These include a Sensor Station demonstrating the role saltwater plays in the Hudson ecosystem, two info kiosks for adults, and a Reading Area aimed at young learners.

We see SENSOR PLACE as an outreach space built to evolve. Your support will help us complete the first phase by installing this amazing watershed exhibit. Additional funds will serve to bring even more inspiring science learning to local families and water lovers of all ages.

In order to maximize the value of your gift, Donor Perks will be available for pickup at our Gallery at 199 Main Street in Beacon, NY. Paperweights can be sent via mail by contacting Asher Pacht at apacht@bire.org.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you feel you cannot contribute funds, you can still help in other ways:

  • Get the word out and let folks know you believe in our campaign!
  • Post our campaign to your Facebook, Twitter or other social network using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
[Edited to add Dec 5th, 2015: The campaign is over, but still want to help? Check out our website! www.fiberartsboston.org]

We want to bring you the most magical, legendary fiber arts tool library that ever existed. We want to help build an awesome community space where anyone regardless of background can make great art, or get started learning how. 

And, by the way, FABRIC is fiscally sponsored by Common Cod Fiber Guild, a 501c3 non-profit.Thus, all donations to FABRIC via Common Cod Fiber Guild are tax deductible, including all Indiegogo donations! 

 

But first, what ARE fiber arts?

Well, a list of example fiber art disciplines include, but is not limited to: sewing (which itself includes making costumes/cosplays, quilting, embroidering) knitting, crocheting, tatting, felting, spinning, weaving, and many, many others!


FABRIC's non-profit mission

To preserve fiber arts for the future through educational classes, a fiber arts library, and the promotion of past and current fiber artists. How are we going to do this? By creating a library of tools and equipment that our members may use at the library or borrow, lots of classes and workshops ranging from basic knitting to advanced corset making, and a traditional book/media library.

FABRIC will be a public space filled with necessary tools for fiber artists and hobbyists alike to create, collaborate, and learn. The goal of this Indiegogo campaign is to raise enough money to rent a space for FABRIC and cover operation costs for one year. Our very first priority is to offer space, and every penny thereafter is a whole other story!

 

The Stuff





The Staff






   

Share this campaign with others! Email friends, relatives, co-workers. Mention us to that random person you always see knitting on the T. Share on Facebook, blog about us, post on Tumblr or Twitter or Livejournal or Ravelry. Let everyone know about FABRIC!

We will be giving away TWO free day passes every day between Nov 20th and Dec 3rd to referrers and donators. We will post the winners every day to our Facebook page, and we will send out a weekly Indiegogo update to announce winners on the following Friday mornings:  Nov 27th for winners Nov 20th-Nov 26th and Dec 4th for winners Nov 27th-Dec 3rd.

Anyone who donates to or refers our campaign gets a chance to win! So please, keep referring this campaign and donating and you'll have a very good chance of winning! (Please be sure to read Indiegogo's explanation of How Referrals Work for the share buttons above. For posts to other social media such as Tumblr, Ravelry, Livejournal, etc, please send an email with a link to your post and your full name to fiberartsboston@gmail.com)

Do you know someone in the Boston area who likes to cosplay? Tell them about us! Do you know anyone who always says they wish they knew how to knit/crochet/quilt/etc.? Tell them to donate to FABRIC, a non-profit that will offer free and paid classes for them to learn all they ever wanted to know and more.

Whatever you do, please help us spread the word! It will help more than we can say in just words.

FABRIC is run by volunteers. If you're interested in volunteering, please let us know at fiberartsboston@gmail.com

How much is this stuff going to cost once you're open?
Currently we expect the costs to be as follows:
For using equipment/tools:
  • $20 for a One Day pass
  • $80 for a pack of 5 One Day passes
  • $150 for a Monthly pass
  • $600 for a Yearly pass
Borrowing items from the book/media library is included for free for Monthly and Yearly pass holders. 

For our more budget conscious fiber lovers, we will be adding student and senior discounts, and other ways for you to save money. There will also be an option to volunteer in exchange for free monthly passes.

We're going to aim for a minimum of 1-2 free classes every week, and 6 or more paid classes every week with an average cost of $30/class. Classes will sometimes have additional material fees.

Hanging out on our couches and working with friends? ALWAYS FREE.

Looking through and reading our books, checking out what we have for tools, enjoying displays of art? ALWAYS FREE.


How will you support vulnerable and underrepresented members of our community?

Well, please forgive us for repeating ourselves a little bit from the question above, because as a non-profit we are very committed to reaching out and supporting ALL fiber artists and hobbyists, regardless of their ability to pay. We very much want to make sure we answer this question thoroughly!

We will have:

  • Senior Citizen discounts
  • Steep discounts for middle & high school students
  • Discounts available to students of any age
  • Volunteer opportunities to work in exchange for free access
  • Grants available for people from low income families


Can a friend and I buy a monthly/yearly pass to share?

Monthly and yearly passes will be strictly digital, stored on our computers. To get in to use the tools, you will first set up an account. Every time thereafter you tell the front desk attendant your account number and PIN, or show your registration email (physical cards available upon request). If you don't mind sharing, we don't mind either, but only one person can use a membership account at a time.



How and when will I get all my stuff?
The tote bag, cup, and bumper sticker from the Exclusive FABRIC Stuff pack will be mailed out starting Dec 14th, through the end of that week via USPS. We will be aiming to order those items around the middle of November, which is why that pack is limited in number. We'd like to see you get your stuff before the end of the third week of December, but of course we cannot make any guarantees on delivery once it is in the hands of USPS during its busiest time of year. If we hit the $125,000 stretch goal, the travel mugs will be ordered either at the same time, or as soon as possible, so that they all go out together.

All passes (day, class, month, year, etc.) will be sent out electronically starting December 10th. You must provide an email address where we can send your passes. NO passes will be physically mailed.

The embroidery tapestry will, understandably, take time to finish. We will email all backers when we start the tapestry, a progress update or two as we work, and a finished update.

The Grand Opening Eve invitation will be emailed to all backers. You will need to show it on a phone or tablet or print it out and show it at the door. Just as with the passes, you must provide an email address where we can send your invitation. NO invitations will be physically mailed.


What happens if you don't meet your goal?

Please see the next question.

When do I get to use my passes? (AKA when does FABRIC open?)
If we successfully raise at least our minimum of $35,000, the Grand Opening will be between April 2016 and June 2016.

It'll take a number of months to find a suitable space, and then it'll take at least two months, maybe longer, to get the space clean and set up. It'll all depend on how fast we find the space, and then once we find it, what kind of shape it's in. We'll be sure to send you guys updates to let you know where we are as we start each new step.

If we don't hit our minimum, it'll depend. Lower than about $25,000 and we will have to wait to find space until we find grant funding to make up the rest of our budget, research time-share options, or other ways to reduce the location costs. Between $25,000 and $35,000 we can start sacrificing other goals (reduce the projected size of the tool library, be further from a T/bus stop than we'd like, etc.) and rent space on the same April/June timeline.


I got a thank you letter from "Boston Knit Out & Crochet", who is that?

Boston Knit Out & Crochet was Common Cod Fiber Guild's previous name.

There are copyright challenges we may face as a media library with books, magazines, and other formats with patterns. Public libraries may buy these materials and lend them, and we should also be able to do so as an educational non-profit, but we may have to change how or what we offer in our "traditional" lending media library based on future copyright challenges. 

Based on what insurance company we get our coverage through, we may have to restrict usage of some tools in the library, such as requiring a signed waiver before they can be used, or only allowing people over a certain age to use certain machines. 

And, of course, like every other for- and non-profit business out there, there is always a chance that some day we will have to close our doors. However, with a strong user base (that's you!) and a good number of volunteers (maybe also you?), we should always be able to keep on offering great working space, educational classes, and a vast array of fiber arts tools for you to use!

mornings:  Nov 27th for winners Nov 20th-Nov 26th and Dec 4th for 
winners Nov 27th-Dec 3rd.Anyone who donates to or refers our campaign gets a chance to win! So please, keep referring this campaign and donating and you'll have a very good chance of winning! (Please be sure to read Indiegogo's explanation of How Referrals Work for the share buttons above. For posts to other social media such as Tumblr, Ravelry, Livejournal, etc, please send an email with a link to your post and your full name to fiberartsboston@gmail.com)


Do you know someone in the Boston area who likes to cosplay? Tell them about us! Do you know anyone who always says they wish they knew how to knit/crochet/quilt/etc.? Tell them to donate to FABRIC, a non-profit that will offer free and paid classes for them to learn all they ever wanted to know and more.

Whatever you do, please help us spread the word! It will help more than we can say in just words.

FABRIC is run by volunteers. If you're interested in volunteering, please let us know at fiberartsboston@gmail.com





How much is this stuff going to cost once you're open?
Currently we expect the costs to be as follows:
For using equipment/tools:


$20 for a One Day pass
$80 for a pack of 5 One Day passes
$150 for a Monthly pass
$600 for a Yearly pass

Borrowing items from the book/media library is included for free for Monthly and Yearly pass holders. 

For our more budget conscious fiber lovers, we will be adding student and senior discounts, and other ways for you to save money. There will also be an option to volunteer in exchange for free monthly passes.



We're going to aim for a minimum of 1-2 free classes every week, and 6 or more paid classes every week with an average cost of $30/class. Classes will sometimes have additional material fees.




Hanging out on our couches and working with friends? ALWAYS FREE.



Looking through and reading our books, checking out what we have for tools, enjoying displays of art? ALWAYS FREE.



How will you support vulnerable and underrepresented members of our community?
Well, please forgive us for repeating ourselves a little bit from the question above, because as a non-profit we are very committed to reaching out and supporting ALL fiber artists and hobbyists, regardless of their ability to pay. We very much want to make sure we answer this question thoroughly!
We will have:


Senior Citizen discounts
Steep discounts for middle & high school students
Discounts available to students of any age
Volunteer opportunities to work in exchange for free access
Grants available for people from low income families


Can a friend and I buy a monthly/yearly pass to share?
Monthly and yearly passes will be strictly digital, stored on our computers. To get in to use the tools, you will first set up an account. Every time thereafter you tell the front desk attendant your account number and PIN, or show your registration email (physical cards available upon request). If you don't mind sharing, we don't mind either, but only one person can use a membership account at a time.



How and when will I get all my stuff?
The tote bag, cup, and bumper sticker from the Exclusive FABRIC Stuff pack will be mailed out starting Dec 14th, through the end of that week via USPS. We will be aiming to order those items around the middle of November, which is why that pack is limited in number. We'd like to see you get your stuff before the end of the third week of December, but of course we cannot make any guarantees on delivery once it is in the hands of USPS during its busiest time of year. If we hit the $125,000 stretch goal, the travel mugs will be ordered either at the same time, or as soon as possible, so that they all go out together.

All passes (day, class, month, year, etc.) will be sent out electronically starting December 10th. You must provide an email address where we can send your passes. NO passes will be physically mailed.

The embroidery tapestry will, understandably, take time to finish. We will email all backers when we start the tapestry, a progress update or two as we work, and a finished update.

The Grand Opening Eve invitation will be emailed to all backers. You will need to show it on a phone or tablet or print it out and show it at the door. Just as with the passes, you must provide an email address where we can send your invitation. NO invitations will be physically mailed.

What happens if you don't meet your goal? Please see the next question.

When do I get to use my passes? (AKA when does FABRIC open?)
If we successfully raise at least our minimum of $35,000, the Grand Opening will be between April 2016 and June 2016.

It'll take a number of months to find a suitable space, and then it'll take at least two months, maybe longer, to get the space clean and set up. It'll all depend on how fast we find the space, and then once we find it, what kind of shape it's in. We'll be sure to send you guys updates to let you know where we are as we start each new step.


If we don't hit our minimum, it'll depend. Lower than about $25,000 and we will have to wait to find space until we find grant funding to make up the rest of our budget, research time-share options, or other ways to reduce the location costs. Between $25,000 and $35,000 we can start sacrificing other goals (reduce the projected size of the tool library, be further from a T/bus stop than we'd like, etc.) and rent space on the same April/June timeline.I got a thank you letter from "Boston Knit Out & Crochet", who is that?Boston Knit Out & Crochet was Common Cod Fiber Guild's previous name.







There are copyright challenges we may face as a media library with books, magazines, and other formats with patterns. Public libraries may buy these materials and lend them, and we should also be able to do so as an educational non-profit, but we may have to change how or what we offer in our "traditional" lending media library based on future copyright challenges. 

Based on what insurance company we get our coverage through, we may have to restrict usage of some tools in the library, such as requiring a signed waiver before they can be used, or only allowing people over a certain age to use certain machines. 

And, of course, like every other for- and non-profit business out there, there is always a chance that some day we will have to close our doors. However, with a strong user base (that's you!) and a good number of volunteers (maybe also you?), we should always be able to keep on offering great working space, educational classes, and a vast array of fiber arts tools for you to use!

story:
Full Story (RO-ENG):

    (RO) Gheorghe Leahu, din raionul Orhei,  în vîrsta de 46 de ani, luptă cu o formă gravă de cancer de gradul 4 (sigmoidian - T4 N2 M1). Este tată a două fete, care fără a-și cruța sănătatea și-a susținut familia, fiind stâlpul casei. Acum el are nevoie de sprijin și ajutor.  

     În Moldova nu e posibilă intervenția chirurgicală, doar peste hotare și este necesară suma 20.000 de dolari . E cumplit să afli că viața unui om atîrna de cîteva mii de dolari, însă e de-a dreptul dramatic cînd îți este înștiințat prețul și ai mîinile legate, pentru că nu dispui de această sumă.

     Gheorghe mai poate spera la viață doar dacă familia ar face rost de bani, printr-o minune, pentru tratament şi operaţie.

     Este unul dintre sutele de cazuri disperate, şi din păcate reale, pentru care merită să facem un efort, să oferim puţin din puţinul nostru, în încercarea de a reda unui om dreptul la viaţă, dreptul de a-și crește copiii.

     Vin cu rugămintea de a-l ajuta și Vă mulțumesc din suflet !

     Orice sumă, oricât de mică, poate face diferenţa dintre disperare şi speranţă. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Oricine doreşte să-l ajute pe Gheorghe o poate face printr-o donaţie în conturile deschise de familie.

     Beneficiar în Moldova: Doinița Leahu

Cod Personal: 2009027010216

Denumirea Bancii: BC ''Moldova Agroindbank'' SA Branch Nr.9, Chisinau

Conturi curente:

SWIFT code: ARGNMD2X434
IBAN: 22522657356 (MDL)

SWIFT code: ARGNMD2X
IBAN: MD33AG000000022522655319 (USD)
IBAN: MD87AG000000022522655317 (EUR)

Telefon pentru informații și donații: +373 79204732 - Doinița Leahu

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(ENG)  George Leahu from Orhei, age 46 years, is struggling with a serious form of cancer Grade 4 (sigmoidian - T4 M1 N2). The father of two daughters, who without always supported his family, without sparing himself. Now he needs help and support from all of us to win this horrifying battle. 

       A surgery is not possible In Moldova, the only chance for survival is a surgery in Austria and the required amount is $ 20,000. It's terrible to know that a man's life hung by a few thousand dollars, but it is even worse not to be able to have this money and to not be able to save his life. All the family is now with hands tied - hoping for a miracle to come and to raise the necessary amount.

      It is one of hundreds of the desperate cases, and unfortunately true, it deserves to make an effort to provide some of what little we have, in trying to give him a hope for life.

      We come with a request for help and want to thank you very much in advance for your support! 

      Any amount, no matter how small, can make the difference between despair and hope.

Beneficiary in Moldova: Doinița Leahu

Fiscal Code: 2009027010216

Beneficiary Bank: BC ''Moldova Agroindbank'' SA Branch Nr.9, Chisinau

Accounts No:

SWIFT code: ARGNMD2X434
IBAN: 22522657356 (MDL)

SWIFT code: ARGNMD2X
IBAN: MD33AG000000022522655319 (USD)
IBAN: MD87AG000000022522655317 (EUR)

Thank you very much!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm andrew chan, from the Philippines.

I'm a engineer, and i like to ASK For HELP materialize a mini ww2 museum in my local place,

I have small collection to show case in the museum but I lack funding and resources. I like to share what i have to the local and foreign to come visit our place And at the same time preserve pieces of history.

The funds, we could generate will go to a medium size shelter to house the museum, other portion will be use to restore, acquire and research about the pieces.

Please Help...


The amount you'll share will help educate, preserve and give a window of history and also help my local town be known...:) Click the heart, to follow my progress

Thank You

Truly

andrew

story:
Hi everybody!

I'm Katie Carlson from Vancouver, Canada. I am an independent gender and development specialist and have been living and working in Rwanda for the last three years.

I recently started a small Canadian non-profit known as Paper Crown Institute with the goal of supporting young girls around the world to become more confident and more knowledgeable, and to achieve whatever goals they set for themselves in life. That's how The Uwicyeza Project began!

The name "Uwicyeza" is a Kinyarwanda word, meaning "the one holding brightness; beautiful and radiant inside and out and making others beautiful and radiant". 

So what is The Uwicyeza Project?

So many of the issues that girls face today are not addressed in traditional education systems or cultural learning, and yet are just as critical for their personal growth, confidence and quality of life. The Uwicyeza Project aims to revolutionize how girls are informed and empowered in Rwanda - outside of the box.

Our goal for this first project in Rwanda is to develop knowledge and practical life skills for secondary school girls in Kigali to help build that kind of lasting self-confidence.

So how exactly will do we do this? We start with six weeks of group workshops focusing on gender and leadership to lay the foundation, but what happens after the classroom?

We head into the field for another six weeks of community development!

What better way to build meaningful and lasting personal confidence in young girls than by giving them the knowledge and skills they’ve been asking for, and then supporting them as they take that newfound knowledge and apply it in real life, with a hands-on group project that directly benefits their own communities? And all while being mentored and coached by teams of accomplished Rwandan women.

Sounds like an awesome idea, no?

But to make all of this happen, we need to raise $13,285 USD to implement the pilot project in Rwanda - and we really hope that you'll want to help! 

So what does the money go towards?

- Managing the project itself for a full five months (an additional one month before implementation for coordination and one month following for evaluation), including developing the curriculum and running the workshops, as well as managing mentoring meetings, overseeing the process of each group's community project and arranging the final project showcase event

- Operational costs, including transportation for students and mentors, internet charges, telephone, venue rental, photographer/videographer fees and group project subsidies for students

- Final project showcase and celebration event, including things like venue rental, tables, chairs, food & drink, A/V equipment, and student completion certificates

The Benefits of Uwicyeza (in a nutshell!)

  • Increased self-confidence
  • Critical thinking and problem solving skills
  • Improved public speaking and personal presentation skills
  • Hands-on practical experience with project management that has a positive social impact
  • Invaluable mentoring relationships with Rwanda's women leaders
  • Vital gender knowledge
  • Awareness and understanding of gender-based violence and resources available to survivors

And who exactly are we?

The Uwicyeza Team and Advisory Council is made up of gender, education and youth experts that have come together voluntarily to make a change for girls in Rwanda. We are comprised of Rwandans, Canadians, and Australians. Our team is based in Rwanda full time with decades of experience in the country. The content developed for the core curriculum is based on critical feedback received from previous workshop participants from the project’s target demographic, as well as on the particular expertise and contextual knowledge of our team.

The Uwicyeza Project is crafted to produce empowered and educated critical thinkers who will stand as visionary leaders and role models for others. Can we count on your support?

Please donate now and SHARE our campaign widely - and don't forget the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for taking the time to check us out!

With love,

Paper Crown and The Uwicyeza Team

story:
Our Goal

Our goal is to build new Green Libraries in two public schools, “Símbolos Patrios” and “Secundaria Técnica n. 223”, located in a slum nearby landfill areas in the municipality of Villa Zaachila - Oaxaca, Mexico.

The Impact

Oaxaca is the second poorest state of Mexico and over 65% of its population faces poverty or extreme poverty levels. It also records a 16.2% of illiteracy rate, which is the highest rate of the country (1.9% of illiteracy rate in the capital, Mexico D.F.). Poverty and illiteracy are two inseparable concepts with mutual negative impacts, and has an even greater negative impact on girls and young women, who have less opportunity than their male peers.

According to the Mexican Council for Evaluation of Social Development Policy (CONEVAL), the municipality of Villa de Zaachila is one of the poorest 133 municipalities of the entire country, with a high incidence of malnutrition, gender disparity and illiteracy.

Since 2008, our non-profit organization - SiKanda, has been working with at-risk communities in Oaxaca, through the implementation of a series of projects focused on fighting poverty, and promoting food security and self-employment in highly marginalized communities in Oaxaca, México.

Through the construction of the Green Libraries, with the active help of the beneficiary families, we lay the groundwork for children’s development. The children who benefit from this initiative come from families comprehending the poverty or extreme poverty levels.  Issues of overweight, malnutrition and high dependence on sugary and industrial foods are common among beneficiaries, which mostly impacts children’s ability to learn.

The parents have an average daily income of $4 to $8 usd. This situation makes impossible for them to buy books for the children and invest more in their education, when most of the families have to worry on how to survive day by day.

The idea is not only to provide an adequate and cozy educational space with over 100 books, which children currently lack of. These spaces will also be used as platforms for community development, environmental and nutrition education and opportunities for the children, where children and families will have training sessions on topics such as health, nutrition, family agriculture and constant follow-up from SiKanda.

With this initiative we intend to have an effect on the structural aspects of poverty, such as: children’s education, environmental awareness in children in order to reduce and reverse the degradation of natural resources and trash accumulation; improve waste management and health levels of families who will be part of these new educational platform, where they will produce organic compost and vegetables as a vehicle to improve nutrition and food.

Through the Green Libraries, we believe we can facilitate children’s learning and self-development, and we hope you can join us in this challenge too!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to complete the construction of 2 New Green libraries and implement educational programs, we need to raise $8400 usd. Part of this money will go towards the construction materials (wood, cement, recyclable materials under a certified, eco-friendly technique) and other part will be used to buy educational materials such as books, pens, whiteboards, and it will also enable SiKanda to organize nutritional and environmental workshops with the families and children.

Depending on the level of your contribution, we are pleased to offer you several gifts from Oaxaca including: a thank you email, bi-monthly updates from SiKanda, a nice picture of the Green Library or a beautiful drawing from the children, SiKanda's documentary about the life of the parents of many of the beneficiary children, or even a personalized video made to you by the children in the library.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell your friends, family and co-workers about SiKanda's important work with the families who live in slums and areas very close to landfills. You can host a party or organize a fundraising event in your community to raise money and awareness for our programs.
